element.definition: Provides the reason in the situation where a reason code is required in addition to the content.
element.comment: For example: the reason for the additional stay, or why a tooth is missing.

binding.name: MissingReason
binding.description: Reason codes for the missing teeth.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this communication by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: instantiatesCanonical
element.definition: The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Communication.

element.name: instantiatesUri
element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Communication.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: An order, proposal or plan fulfilled in whole or in part by this Communication.
element.comment: This must point to some sort of a 'Request' resource, such as CarePlan, CommunicationRequest, ServiceRequest, MedicationRequest, etc.

element.name: partOf
element.definition: Part of this action.

element.name: inResponseTo
element.definition: Prior communication that this communication is in response to.

element.name: status
element.description: preparation | in-progress | not-done | on-hold | stopped | completed | entered-in-error | unknown
element.definition: The status of the transmission.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes aborted and entered-in-error that mark the communication as not currently valid.

binding.name: CommunicationStatus
binding.description: The status of the communication.

element.name: statusReason
element.definition: Captures the reason for the current state of the Communication.
element.comment: This is generally only used for "exception" statuses such as "not-done", "suspended" or "aborted". The reason for performing the event at all is captured in reasonCode, not here.

binding.name: CommunicationNotDoneReason
binding.description: Codes for the reason why a communication did not happen.

element.name: category
element.definition: The type of message conveyed such as alert, notification, reminder, instruction, etc.
element.comment: There may be multiple axes of categorization and one communication may serve multiple purposes.

binding.name: CommunicationCategory
binding.description: Codes for general categories of communications such as alerts, instructions, etc.

element.name: priority
element.definition: Characterizes how quickly the planned or in progress communication must be addressed. Includes concepts such as stat, urgent, routine.
element.comment: Used to prioritize workflow (such as which communication to read first) when the communication is planned or in progress.

binding.name: CommunicationPriority
binding.description: Codes indicating the relative importance of a communication.

element.name: medium
element.definition: A channel that was used for this communication (e.g. email, fax).

binding.name: CommunicationMedium
binding.description: Codes for communication mediums such as phone, fax, email, in person, etc.

element.name: subject
element.definition: The patient or group that was the focus of this communication.

element.name: topic
element.definition: Description of the purpose/content, similar to a subject line in an email.
element.comment: Communication.topic.text can be used without any codings.

binding.name: CommunicationTopic
binding.description: Codes describing the purpose or content of the communication.

element.name: about
element.description: Resources that pertain to this communication
element.definition: Other resources that pertain to this communication and to which this communication should be associated.
element.comment: Don't use Communication.about element when a more specific element exists, such as basedOn or reasonReference.

element.name: encounter
element.definition: The Encounter during which this Communication was created or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some activities may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter.

element.name: sent
element.definition: The time when this communication was sent.

element.name: received
element.definition: The time when this communication arrived at the destination.

element.name: recipient
element.definition: The entity (e.g. person, organization, clinical information system, care team or device) which was the target of the communication. If receipts need to be tracked by an individual, a separate resource instance will need to be created for each recipient. Multiple recipient communications are intended where either receipts are not tracked (e.g. a mass mail-out) or a receipt is captured in aggregate (all emails confirmed received by a particular time).

element.name: sender
element.definition: The entity (e.g. person, organization, clinical information system, or device) which was the source of the communication.

element.name: reasonCode
element.definition: The reason or justification for the communication.
element.comment: Textual reasons can be captured using reasonCode.text.

binding.name: CommunicationReason
binding.description: Codes for describing reasons for the occurrence of a communication.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Indicates another resource whose existence justifies this communication.

element.name: payload
element.definition: Text, attachment(s), or resource(s) that was communicated to the recipient.

element.name: note
element.definition: Additional notes or commentary about the communication by the sender, receiver or other interested parties.

element.name: content
element.definition: A communicated content (or for multi-part communications, one portion of the communication).

element.name: recorded
element.definition: Captures the recorded date of the event.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this communication by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: instantiatesCanonical
element.definition: The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Communication.

element.name: instantiatesUri
element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Communication.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: An order, proposal or plan fulfilled in whole or in part by this Communication.
element.comment: This must point to some sort of a 'Request' resource, such as CarePlan, CommunicationRequest, ServiceRequest, MedicationRequest, etc.

element.name: partOf
element.definition: Part of this action.

element.name: inResponseTo
element.definition: Prior communication that this communication is in response to.

element.name: status
element.description: preparation | in-progress | not-done | on-hold | stopped | completed | entered-in-error | unknown
element.definition: The status of the transmission.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes aborted and entered-in-error that mark the communication as not currently valid.

binding.name: CommunicationStatus
binding.description: The status of the communication.

element.name: statusReason
element.definition: Captures the reason for the current state of the Communication.
element.comment: This is generally only used for "exception" statuses such as "not-done", "suspended" or "aborted". The reason for performing the event at all is captured in reasonCode, not here.

element.name: category
element.definition: The type of message conveyed such as alert, notification, reminder, instruction, etc.
element.comment: There may be multiple axes of categorization and one communication may serve multiple purposes.

binding.name: CommunicationCategory
binding.description: Codes for general categories of communications such as alerts, instructions, etc.

element.name: priority
element.definition: Characterizes how quickly the planned or in progress communication must be addressed. Includes concepts such as stat, urgent, routine.
element.comment: Used to prioritize workflow (such as which communication to read first) when the communication is planned or in progress.

binding.name: CommunicationPriority
binding.description: Codes indicating the relative importance of a communication.

element.name: medium
element.definition: A channel that was used for this communication (e.g. email, fax).

binding.name: CommunicationMedium
binding.description: Codes for communication mediums such as phone, fax, email, in person, etc.

element.name: subject
element.definition: The patient or group that was the focus of this communication.

element.name: topic
element.definition: Description of the purpose/content, similar to a subject line in an email.
element.comment: Communication.topic.text can be used without any codings.

binding.name: CommunicationTopic
binding.description: Codes describing the purpose or content of the communication.

element.name: about
element.description: Resources that pertain to this communication
element.definition: Other resources that pertain to this communication and to which this communication should be associated.
element.comment: Don't use Communication.about element when a more specific element exists, such as basedOn or reasonReference.

element.name: encounter
element.definition: The Encounter during which this Communication was created or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some activities may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter.

element.name: sent
element.definition: The time when this communication was sent.

element.name: received
element.definition: The time when this communication arrived at the destination.

element.name: recipient
element.definition: The entity (e.g. person, organization, clinical information system, care team or device) which was the target of the communication. If receipts need to be tracked by an individual, a separate resource instance will need to be created for each recipient. Multiple recipient communications are intended where either receipts are not tracked (e.g. a mass mail-out) or a receipt is captured in aggregate (all emails confirmed received by a particular time).

element.name: sender
element.definition: The entity (e.g. person, organization, clinical information system, or device) which was the source of the communication.

element.name: reasonCode
element.definition: The reason or justification for the communication.
element.comment: Textual reasons can be captured using reasonCode.text.

binding.name: CommunicationReason
binding.description: Codes for describing reasons for the occurrence of a communication.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Indicates another resource whose existence justifies this communication.

element.name: payload
element.definition: Text, attachment(s), or resource(s) that was communicated to the recipient.

element.name: note
element.definition: Additional notes or commentary about the communication by the sender, receiver or other interested parties.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this communication request by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: A plan or proposal that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this request.

element.name: replaces
element.definition: Completed or terminated request(s) whose function is taken by this new request.
element.comment: The replacement could be because the initial request was immediately rejected (due to an issue) or because the previous request was completed, but the need for the action described by the request remains ongoing.

element.name: groupIdentifier
element.description: Composite request this is part of
element.definition: A shared identifier common to all requests that were authorized more or less simultaneously by a single author, representing the identifier of the requisition, prescription or similar form.
element.comment: Requests are linked either by a "basedOn" relationship (i.e. one request is fulfilling another) or by having a common requisition. Requests that are part of the same requisition are generally treated independently from the perspective of changing their state or maintaining them after initial creation.

element.name: status
element.description: draft | active | on-hold | revoked | completed | entered-in-error | unknown
element.definition: The status of the proposal or order.

binding.name: CommunicationRequestStatus
binding.description: The status of the communication request.

element.name: statusReason
element.definition: Captures the reason for the current state of the CommunicationRequest.
element.comment: This is generally only used for "exception" statuses such as "suspended" or "cancelled". The reason why the CommunicationRequest was created at all is captured in reasonCode, not here. [distinct reason codes for different statuses can be enforced using invariants if they are universal bindings].

binding.name: CommunicationRequestStatusReason
binding.description: Codes identifying the reason for the current state of a request.

element.name: category
element.definition: The type of message to be sent such as alert, notification, reminder, instruction, etc.
element.comment: There may be multiple axes of categorization and one communication request may serve multiple purposes.

binding.name: CommunicationCategory
binding.description: Codes for general categories of communications such as alerts, instruction, etc.

element.name: priority
element.definition: Characterizes how quickly the proposed act must be initiated. Includes concepts such as stat, urgent, routine.

binding.name: CommunicationPriority
binding.description: Codes indicating the relative importance of a communication request.

element.name: doNotPerform
element.description: True if request is prohibiting action
element.definition: If true indicates that the CommunicationRequest is asking for the specified action to *not* occur.
element.comment: The attributes provided with the request qualify what is not to be done.

element.name: medium
element.definition: A channel that was used for this communication (e.g. email, fax).

binding.name: CommunicationMedium
binding.description: Codes for communication mediums such as phone, fax, email, in person, etc.

element.name: subject
element.definition: The patient or group that is the focus of this communication request.

element.name: about
element.description: Resources that pertain to this communication request
element.definition: Other resources that pertain to this communication request and to which this communication request should be associated.
element.comment: Don't use CommunicationRequest.about element when a more specific element exists, such as basedOn, reasonReference, or replaces.

element.name: encounter
element.definition: The Encounter during which this CommunicationRequest was created or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some activities may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter.

element.name: payload
element.definition: Text, attachment(s), or resource(s) to be communicated to the recipient.

element.name: occurrence
element.definition: The time when this communication is to occur.

element.name: authoredOn
element.description: When request transitioned to being actionable
element.definition: For draft requests, indicates the date of initial creation. For requests with other statuses, indicates the date of activation.

element.name: requester
element.definition: The device, individual, or organization who initiated the request and has responsibility for its activation.

element.name: recipient
element.definition: The entity (e.g. person, organization, clinical information system, device, group, or care team) which is the intended target of the communication.

element.name: sender
element.definition: The entity (e.g. person, organization, clinical information system, or device) which is to be the source of the communication.

element.name: reasonCode
element.definition: Describes why the request is being made in coded or textual form.
element.comment: Textual reasons can be captured using reasonCode.text.

binding.name: CommunicationReason
binding.description: Codes for describing reasons for the occurrence of a communication.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Indicates another resource whose existence justifies this request.

element.name: note
element.definition: Comments made about the request by the requester, sender, recipient, subject or other participants.

element.name: content
element.definition: The communicated content (or for multi-part communications, one portion of the communication).

element.name: dueTo
element.definition: Further conditions, problems, diagnoses, procedures or events or the substance that caused/triggered this Condition.
element.comment: Although a condition may be caused by a substance, this is not intended to be used to record allergies/adverse reactions to substances.

element.name: occurredFollowing
element.definition: Further conditions, problems, diagnoses, procedures or events or the substance that preceded this Condition.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this condition by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: clinicalStatus
element.description: active | recurrence | relapse | inactive | remission | resolved
element.definition: The clinical status of the condition.
element.comment: The data type is CodeableConcept because clinicalStatus has some clinical judgment involved, such that there might need to be more specificity than the required FHIR value set allows. For example, a SNOMED coding might allow for additional specificity.

element.name: verificationStatus
element.description: unconfirmed | provisional | differential | confirmed | refuted | entered-in-error
element.definition: The verification status to support the clinical status of the condition.
element.comment: verificationStatus is not required. For example, when a patient has abdominal pain in the ED, there is not likely going to be a verification status. The data type is CodeableConcept because verificationStatus has some clinical judgment involved, such that there might need to be more specificity than the required FHIR value set allows. For example, a SNOMED coding might allow for additional specificity.

element.name: category
element.definition: A category assigned to the condition.
element.comment: The categorization is often highly contextual and may appear poorly differentiated or not very useful in other contexts.

element.name: severity
element.definition: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.
element.comment: Coding of the severity with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

binding.name: ConditionSeverity
binding.description: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.

element.name: code
element.description: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis
element.definition: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis.

binding.description: Valueset to describe the actual problem experienced by the patient

element.name: bodySite
element.definition: The anatomical location where this condition manifests itself.
element.comment: Only used if not implicit in code found in Condition.code. If the use case requires attributes from the BodySite resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [bodySite](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-bodysite.html). May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.name: subject
element.definition: Indicates the patient or group who the condition record is associated with.

element.name: encounter
element.definition: The Encounter during which this Condition was created or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some activities may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter. This record indicates the encounter this particular record is associated with. In the case of a "new" diagnosis reflecting ongoing/revised information about the condition, this might be distinct from the first encounter in which the underlying condition was first "known".

element.name: onset
element.description: Estimated or actual date, date-time, or age
element.definition: Estimated or actual date or date-time the condition began, in the opinion of the clinician.
element.comment: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition began to occur.

element.name: abatement
element.definition: The date or estimated date that the condition resolved or went into remission. This is called "abatement" because of the many overloaded connotations associated with "remission" or "resolution" - Conditions are never really resolved, but they can abate.
element.comment: There is no explicit distinction between resolution and remission because in many cases the distinction is not clear. Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition abated. If there is no abatement element, it is unknown whether the condition has resolved or entered remission; applications and users should generally assume that the condition is still valid. When abatementString exists, it implies the condition is abated.

element.name: recordedDate
element.definition: The recordedDate represents when this particular Condition record was created in the system, which is often a system-generated date.

element.name: recorder
element.definition: Individual who recorded the record and takes responsibility for its content.

element.name: asserter
element.definition: Individual who is making the condition statement.

element.name: stage
element.definition: Clinical stage or grade of a condition. May include formal severity assessments.

constraint.name: con-1
constraint.message: Stage SHALL have summary or assessment

element.name: evidence
element.definition: Supporting evidence / manifestations that are the basis of the Condition's verification status, such as evidence that confirmed or refuted the condition.
element.comment: The evidence may be a simple list of coded symptoms/manifestations, or references to observations or formal assessments, or both.

constraint.name: con-2
constraint.message: evidence SHALL have code or details

element.name: note
element.definition: Additional information about the Condition. This is a general notes/comments entry for description of the Condition, its diagnosis and prognosis.

element.name: code
element.definition: A manifestation or symptom that led to the recording of this condition.

binding.name: ManifestationOrSymptom
binding.description: Codes that describe the manifestation or symptoms of a condition.

element.name: detail
element.definition: Links to other relevant information, including pathology reports.

element.name: summary
element.definition: A simple summary of the stage such as "Stage 3". The determination of the stage is disease-specific.

binding.name: ConditionStage
binding.description: Codes describing condition stages (e.g. Cancer stages).

element.name: assessment
element.definition: Reference to a formal record of the evidence on which the staging assessment is based.

element.name: type
element.definition: The kind of staging, such as pathological or clinical staging.

binding.name: ConditionStageType
binding.description: Codes describing the kind of condition staging (e.g. clinical or pathological).

element.name: name
element.description: Name of an individual to contact
element.definition: The name of an individual to contact.
element.comment: If there is no named individual, the telecom information is for the organization as a whole.

element.name: telecom
element.description: Contact details for individual or organization
element.definition: The contact details for the individual (if a name was provided) or the organization.

element.name: system
element.description: phone | fax | email | pager | url | sms | other
element.definition: Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.

binding.name: ContactPointSystem
binding.description: Telecommunications form for contact point.

element.name: value
element.definition: The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
element.comment: Additional text data such as phone extension numbers, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value.

element.name: use
element.description: home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this contact point
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point.
element.comment: Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.

binding.name: ContactPointUse
binding.description: Use of contact point.

element.name: rank
element.description: Specify preferred order of use (1 = highest)
element.definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. ContactPoints with lower rank values are more preferred than those with higher rank values.
element.comment: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.

element.name: period
element.description: Time period when the contact point was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when the contact point was/is in use.

element.name: type
element.definition: The type of contributor.

binding.name: ContributorType
binding.description: The type of contributor.

element.name: name
element.definition: The name of the individual or organization responsible for the contribution.

element.name: contact
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the contributor.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: A unique identifier assigned to this coverage.
element.comment: The main (and possibly only) identifier for the coverage - often referred to as a Member Id, Certificate number, Personal Health Number or Case ID. May be constructed as the concatenation of the Coverage.SubscriberID and the Coverage.dependant.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of the resource instance.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the code entered-in-error that marks the coverage as not currently valid.

binding.name: CoverageStatus
binding.description: A code specifying the state of the resource instance.

element.name: type
element.description: Coverage category such as medical or accident
element.definition: The type of coverage: social program, medical plan, accident coverage (workers compensation, auto), group health or payment by an individual or organization.

binding.description: Categories of types of health care payor entities as defined by the US Public Health Data Consortium SOP code system

element.name: policyHolder
element.definition: The party who 'owns' the insurance policy.
element.comment: For example: may be an individual, corporation or the subscriber's employer.

element.name: subscriber
element.definition: The party who has signed-up for or 'owns' the contractual relationship to the policy or to whom the benefit of the policy for services rendered to them or their family is due.
element.comment: May be self or a parent in the case of dependants.

element.name: subscriberId
element.definition: The insurer assigned ID for the Subscriber.

element.name: beneficiary
element.definition: The party who benefits from the insurance coverage; the patient when products and/or services are provided.

element.name: dependent
element.definition: A unique identifier for a dependent under the coverage.
element.comment: Periodically the member number is constructed from the subscriberId and the dependant number.

element.name: relationship
element.definition: The relationship of beneficiary (patient) to the subscriber.
element.comment: Typically, an individual uses policies which are theirs (relationship='self') before policies owned by others.

binding.name: Relationship
binding.description: The relationship between the Subscriber and the Beneficiary (insured/covered party/patient).

element.name: period
element.definition: Time period during which the coverage is in force. A missing start date indicates the start date isn't known, a missing end date means the coverage is continuing to be in force.

element.name: payor
element.definition: The program or plan underwriter or payor including both insurance and non-insurance agreements, such as patient-pay agreements.
element.comment: May provide multiple identifiers such as insurance company identifier or business identifier (BIN number). For selfpay it may provide multiple paying persons and/or organizations.

element.name: class
element.definition: A suite of underwriter specific classifiers.
element.comment: For example may be used to identify a class of coverage or employer group, Policy, Plan.

element.name: order
element.definition: The order of applicability of this coverage relative to other coverages which are currently in force. Note, there may be gaps in the numbering and this does not imply primary, secondary etc. as the specific positioning of coverages depends upon the episode of care.

element.name: network
element.definition: The insurer-specific identifier for the insurer-defined network of providers to which the beneficiary may seek treatment which will be covered at the 'in-network' rate, otherwise 'out of network' terms and conditions apply.

element.name: costToBeneficiary
element.definition: A suite of codes indicating the cost category and associated amount which have been detailed in the policy and may have been included on the health card.
element.comment: For example by knowing the patient visit co-pay, the provider can collect the amount prior to undertaking treatment.

element.name: subrogation
element.definition: When 'subrogation=true' this insurance instance has been included not for adjudication but to provide insurers with the details to recover costs.
element.comment: Typically, automotive and worker's compensation policies would be flagged with 'subrogation=true' to enable healthcare payors to collect against accident claims.

element.name: contract
element.definition: The policy(s) which constitute this insurance coverage.

element.name: type
element.description: Type of class such as 'group' or 'plan'
element.definition: The type of classification for which an insurer-specific class label or number and optional name is provided, for example may be used to identify a class of coverage or employer group, Policy, Plan.

binding.name: CoverageClass
binding.description: The policy classifications, eg. Group, Plan, Class, etc.

element.name: value
element.definition: The alphanumeric string value associated with the insurer issued label.
element.comment: For example, the Group or Plan number.

element.name: name
element.description: Human readable description of the type and value
element.definition: A short description for the class.

element.name: type
element.definition: The category of patient centric costs associated with treatment.
element.comment: For example visit, specialist visits, emergency, inpatient care, etc.

binding.name: CopayTypes
binding.description: The types of services to which patient copayments are specified.

element.name: value
element.description: The amount or percentage due from the beneficiary
element.definition: The amount due from the patient for the cost category.
element.comment: Amount may be expressed as a percentage of the service/product cost or a fixed amount of currency.

element.name: exception
element.definition: A suite of codes indicating exceptions or reductions to patient costs and their effective periods.

element.name: type
element.definition: The code for the specific exception.

binding.name: CoverageFinancialException
binding.description: The types of exceptions from the part or full value of financial obligations such as copays.

element.name: period
element.description: The effective period of the exception
element.definition: The timeframe during when the exception is in force.

element.name: type
element.description: The type of the required data
element.definition: The type of the required data, specified as the type name of a resource. For profiles, this value is set to the type of the base resource of the profile.

binding.name: FHIRAllTypes
binding.description: A list of all the concrete types defined in this version of the FHIR specification - Abstract Types, Data Types and Resource Types.

element.name: profile
element.description: The profile of the required data
element.definition: The profile of the required data, specified as the uri of the profile definition.

element.name: subject
element.description: E.g. Patient, Practitioner, RelatedPerson, Organization, Location, Device
element.definition: The intended subjects of the data requirement. If this element is not provided, a Patient subject is assumed.
element.comment: The subject of a data requirement is critical, as the data being specified is determined with respect to a particular subject. This corresponds roughly to the notion of a Compartment in that it limits what data is available based on its relationship to the subject. In CQL, this corresponds to the context declaration.

binding.name: SubjectType
binding.description: The possible types of subjects for a data requirement (E.g., Patient, Practitioner, Organization, Location, etc.).

element.name: mustSupport
element.description: Indicates specific structure elements that are referenced by the knowledge module
element.definition:
Indicates that specific elements of the type are referenced by the knowledge module and must be supported by the consumer in order to obtain an effective evaluation. This does not mean that a value is required for this element, only that the consuming system must understand the element and be able to provide values for it if they are available.
The value of mustSupport SHALL be a FHIRPath resolveable on the type of the DataRequirement. The path SHALL consist only of identifiers, constant indexers, and .resolve() (see the [Simple FHIRPath Profile](fhirpath.html#simple) for full details).

element.name: codeFilter
element.definition: Code filters specify additional constraints on the data, specifying the value set of interest for a particular element of the data. Each code filter defines an additional constraint on the data, i.e. code filters are AND'ed, not OR'ed.

constraint.name: drq-1
constraint.message: Either a path or a searchParam must be provided, but not both

element.name: dateFilter
element.definition: Date filters specify additional constraints on the data in terms of the applicable date range for specific elements. Each date filter specifies an additional constraint on the data, i.e. date filters are AND'ed, not OR'ed.

constraint.name: drq-2
constraint.message: Either a path or a searchParam must be provided, but not both

element.name: limit
element.definition: Specifies a maximum number of results that are required (uses the _count search parameter).
element.comment: This element can be used in combination with the sort element to specify quota requirements such as "the most recent 5" or "the highest 5".

element.name: sort
element.definition: Specifies the order of the results to be returned.
element.comment: This element can be used in combination with the sort element to specify quota requirements such as "the most recent 5" or "the highest 5". When multiple sorts are specified, they are applied in the order they appear in the resource.

element.name: path
element.description: A code-valued attribute to filter on
element.definition: The code-valued attribute of the filter. The specified path SHALL be a FHIRPath resolveable on the specified type of the DataRequirement, and SHALL consist only of identifiers, constant indexers, and .resolve(). The path is allowed to contain qualifiers (.) to traverse sub-elements, as well as indexers ([x]) to traverse multiple-cardinality sub-elements (see the [Simple FHIRPath Profile](fhirpath.html#simple) for full details). Note that the index must be an integer constant. The path must resolve to an element of type code, Coding, or CodeableConcept.
element.comment: The path attribute contains a [Simple FHIRPath Subset](fhirpath.html#simple) that allows path traversal, but not calculation.

element.name: searchParam
element.description: A coded (token) parameter to search on
element.definition: A token parameter that refers to a search parameter defined on the specified type of the DataRequirement, and which searches on elements of type code, Coding, or CodeableConcept.

element.name: valueSet
element.definition: The valueset for the code filter. The valueSet and code elements are additive. If valueSet is specified, the filter will return only those data items for which the value of the code-valued element specified in the path is a member of the specified valueset.

element.name: code
element.definition: The codes for the code filter. If values are given, the filter will return only those data items for which the code-valued attribute specified by the path has a value that is one of the specified codes. If codes are specified in addition to a value set, the filter returns items matching a code in the value set or one of the specified codes.

element.name: path
element.description: A date-valued attribute to filter on
element.definition: The date-valued attribute of the filter. The specified path SHALL be a FHIRPath resolveable on the specified type of the DataRequirement, and SHALL consist only of identifiers, constant indexers, and .resolve(). The path is allowed to contain qualifiers (.) to traverse sub-elements, as well as indexers ([x]) to traverse multiple-cardinality sub-elements (see the [Simple FHIRPath Profile](fhirpath.html#simple) for full details). Note that the index must be an integer constant. The path must resolve to an element of type date, dateTime, Period, Schedule, or Timing.
element.comment: The path attribute contains a [Simple FHIR Subset](fhirpath.html#simple) that allows path traversal, but not calculation.

element.name: searchParam
element.description: A date valued parameter to search on
element.definition: A date parameter that refers to a search parameter defined on the specified type of the DataRequirement, and which searches on elements of type date, dateTime, Period, Schedule, or Timing.

element.name: value
element.description: The value of the filter, as a Period, DateTime, or Duration value
element.definition: The value of the filter. If period is specified, the filter will return only those data items that fall within the bounds determined by the Period, inclusive of the period boundaries. If dateTime is specified, the filter will return only those data items that are equal to the specified dateTime. If a Duration is specified, the filter will return only those data items that fall within Duration before now.

element.name: path
element.description: The name of the attribute to perform the sort
element.definition: The attribute of the sort. The specified path must be resolvable from the type of the required data. The path is allowed to contain qualifiers (.) to traverse sub-elements, as well as indexers ([x]) to traverse multiple-cardinality sub-elements. Note that the index must be an integer constant.

element.name: direction
element.definition: The direction of the sort, ascending or descending.

binding.name: SortDirection
binding.description: The possible sort directions, ascending or descending.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Unique instance identifiers assigned to a device by manufacturers other organizations or owners.
element.comment: The barcode string from a barcode present on a device label or package may identify the instance, include names given to the device in local usage, or may identify the type of device. If the identifier identifies the type of device, Device.type element should be used.

element.name: definition
element.description: The reference to the definition for the device
element.definition: The reference to the definition for the device.

element.name: udiCarrier
element.definition: Unique device identifier (UDI) assigned to device label or package. Note that the Device may include multiple udiCarriers as it either may include just the udiCarrier for the jurisdiction it is sold, or for multiple jurisdictions it could have been sold.
element.comment: UDI may identify an unique instance of a device, or it may only identify the type of the device. See [UDI mappings](device-mappings.html#udi) for a complete mapping of UDI parts to Device.

element.name: status
element.definition: Status of the Device availability.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes inactive and entered-in-error that mark the device (record)as not currently valid.

binding.name: FHIRDeviceStatus
binding.description: The availability status of the device.

element.name: statusReason
element.description: online | paused | standby | offline | not-ready | transduc-discon | hw-discon | off
element.definition: Reason for the dtatus of the Device availability.

binding.name: FHIRDeviceStatusReason
binding.description: The availability status reason of the device.

element.name: distinctIdentifier
element.definition: The distinct identification string as required by regulation for a human cell, tissue, or cellular and tissue-based product.
element.comment: For example, this applies to devices in the United States regulated under *Code of Federal Regulation 21CFR§1271.290(c)*.

element.name: manufacturer
element.definition: A name of the manufacturer.

element.name: manufactureDate
element.description: Date when the device was made
element.definition: The date and time when the device was manufactured.

element.name: expirationDate
element.description: Date and time of expiry of this device (if applicable)
element.definition: The date and time beyond which this device is no longer valid or should not be used (if applicable).

element.name: lotNumber
element.definition: Lot number assigned by the manufacturer.

element.name: serialNumber
element.description: Serial number assigned by the manufacturer
element.definition: The serial number assigned by the organization when the device was manufactured.
element.comment: Alphanumeric Maximum 20.

element.name: deviceName
element.description: The name of the device as given by the manufacturer
element.definition: This represents the manufacturer's name of the device as provided by the device, from a UDI label, or by a person describing the Device. This typically would be used when a person provides the name(s) or when the device represents one of the names available from DeviceDefinition.

element.name: modelNumber
element.description: The model number for the device
element.definition: The model number for the device.

element.name: partNumber
element.description: The part number of the device
element.definition: The part number of the device.
element.comment: Alphanumeric Maximum 20.

element.name: type
element.description: The kind or type of device
element.definition: The kind or type of device.

binding.name: DeviceType
binding.description: Codes to identify medical devices.

element.name: specialization
element.description: The capabilities supported on a device, the standards to which the device conforms for a particular purpose, and used for the communication
element.definition: The capabilities supported on a device, the standards to which the device conforms for a particular purpose, and used for the communication.

element.name: version
element.description: The actual design of the device or software version running on the device
element.definition: The actual design of the device or software version running on the device.

element.name: property
element.description: The actual configuration settings of a device as it actually operates, e.g., regulation status, time properties
element.definition: The actual configuration settings of a device as it actually operates, e.g., regulation status, time properties.

element.name: patient
element.description: Patient to whom Device is affixed
element.definition: Patient information, If the device is affixed to a person.

element.name: owner
element.definition: An organization that is responsible for the provision and ongoing maintenance of the device.

element.name: contact
element.definition: Contact details for an organization or a particular human that is responsible for the device.
element.comment: used for troubleshooting etc.

element.name: location
element.definition: The place where the device can be found.

element.name: url
element.definition: A network address on which the device may be contacted directly.
element.comment: If the device is running a FHIR server, the network address should be the Base URL from which a conformance statement may be retrieved.

element.name: note
element.definition: Descriptive information, usage information or implantation information that is not captured in an existing element.

element.name: safety
element.definition: Provides additional safety characteristics about a medical device. For example devices containing latex.

element.name: parent
element.definition: The parent device.

element.name: name
element.definition: The name of the device.

element.name: type
element.description: udi-label-name | user-friendly-name | patient-reported-name | manufacturer-name | model-name | other
element.definition: The type of deviceName. UDILabelName | UserFriendlyName | PatientReportedName | ManufactureDeviceName | ModelName.

binding.name: DeviceNameType
binding.description: The type of name the device is referred by.

element.name: type
element.description: Code that specifies the property DeviceDefinitionPropetyCode (Extensible)
element.definition: Code that specifies the property DeviceDefinitionPropetyCode (Extensible).

element.name: valueQuantity
element.definition: Property value as a quantity.

element.name: valueCode
element.description: Property value as a code, e.g., NTP4 (synced to NTP)
element.definition: Property value as a code, e.g., NTP4 (synced to NTP).

element.name: systemType
element.description: The standard that is used to operate and communicate
element.definition: The standard that is used to operate and communicate.

element.name: version
element.description: The version of the standard that is used to operate and communicate
element.definition: The version of the standard that is used to operate and communicate.

element.name: deviceIdentifier
element.definition: The device identifier (DI) is a mandatory, fixed portion of a UDI that identifies the labeler and the specific version or model of a device.

element.name: issuer
element.definition: Organization that is charged with issuing UDIs for devices. For example, the US FDA issuers include : 1) GS1: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/gs1-di, 2) HIBCC: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/hibcc-dI, 3) ICCBBA for blood containers: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/iccbba-blood-di, 4) ICCBA for other devices: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/iccbba-other-di.

element.name: jurisdiction
element.definition: The identity of the authoritative source for UDI generation within a jurisdiction. All UDIs are globally unique within a single namespace with the appropriate repository uri as the system. For example, UDIs of devices managed in the U.S. by the FDA, the value is http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/fda-udi.

element.name: carrierAIDC
element.definition: The full UDI carrier of the Automatic Identification and Data Capture (AIDC) technology representation of the barcode string as printed on the packaging of the device - e.g., a barcode or RFID. Because of limitations on character sets in XML and the need to round-trip JSON data through XML, AIDC Formats *SHALL* be base64 encoded.
element.comment: The AIDC form of UDIs should be scanned or otherwise used for the identification of the device whenever possible to minimize errors in records resulting from manual transcriptions. If separate barcodes for DI and PI are present, concatenate the string with DI first and in order of human readable expression on label.

element.name: carrierHRF
element.definition: The full UDI carrier as the human readable form (HRF) representation of the barcode string as printed on the packaging of the device.
element.comment: If separate barcodes for DI and PI are present, concatenate the string with DI first and in order of human readable expression on label.

element.name: entryType
element.definition: A coded entry to indicate how the data was entered.

binding.name: UDIEntryType
binding.description: Codes to identify how UDI data was entered.

element.name: type
element.description: The type of the device version
element.definition: The type of the device version.

element.name: component
element.description: A single component of the device version
element.definition: A single component of the device version.

element.name: value
element.definition: The version text.

element.name: doNotPerformReason
element.definition: Indicates the reason the event was not performed.

element.name: doNotPerform
element.definition: An Extension

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Identifiers assigned to this order by the orderer or by the receiver.

element.name: instantiatesCanonical
element.definition: The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this DeviceRequest.
element.comment: Note: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: instantiatesUri
element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this DeviceRequest.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: Plan/proposal/order fulfilled by this request.

element.name: priorRequest
element.definition: The request takes the place of the referenced completed or terminated request(s).

element.name: groupIdentifier
element.definition: Composite request this is part of.

element.name: status
element.description: draft | active | on-hold | revoked | completed | entered-in-error | unknown
element.definition: The status of the request.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes cancelled and entered-in-error that mark the request as not currently valid.

binding.name: DeviceRequestStatus
binding.description: Codes representing the status of the request.

element.name: intent
element.description: proposal | plan | directive | order | original-order | reflex-order | filler-order | instance-order | option
element.definition: Whether the request is a proposal, plan, an original order or a reflex order.

binding.name: RequestIntent
binding.description: The kind of diagnostic request.

element.name: priority
element.definition: Indicates how quickly the {{title}} should be addressed with respect to other requests.

binding.name: RequestPriority
binding.description: Identifies the level of importance to be assigned to actioning the request.

element.name: code
element.definition: The details of the device to be used.

binding.name: DeviceRequestCode
binding.description: Codes for devices that can be requested.

element.name: parameter
element.definition: Specific parameters for the ordered item. For example, the prism value for lenses.

element.name: subject
element.definition: The patient who will use the device.

element.name: encounter
element.definition: An encounter that provides additional context in which this request is made.

element.name: occurrence
element.description: Desired time or schedule for use
element.definition: The timing schedule for the use of the device. The Schedule data type allows many different expressions, for example. "Every 8 hours"; "Three times a day"; "1/2 an hour before breakfast for 10 days from 23-Dec 2011:"; "15 Oct 2013, 17 Oct 2013 and 1 Nov 2013".

element.name: authoredOn
element.definition: When the request transitioned to being actionable.

element.name: requester
element.definition: The individual who initiated the request and has responsibility for its activation.

element.name: performerType
element.definition: Desired type of performer for doing the diagnostic testing.

binding.name: DeviceRequestParticipantRole
binding.description: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care team, such as "Primary physician", "Team coordinator", "Caregiver", etc.

element.name: performer
element.definition: The desired performer for doing the diagnostic testing.

element.name: reasonCode
element.definition: Reason or justification for the use of this device.

binding.name: DeviceRequestReason
binding.description: Diagnosis or problem codes justifying the reason for requesting the device.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Reason or justification for the use of this device.

element.name: insurance
element.definition: Insurance plans, coverage extensions, pre-authorizations and/or pre-determinations that may be required for delivering the requested service.

element.name: supportingInfo
element.definition: Additional clinical information about the patient that may influence the request fulfilment. For example, this may include where on the subject's body the device will be used (i.e. the target site).

element.name: note
element.definition: Details about this request that were not represented at all or sufficiently in one of the attributes provided in a class. These may include for example a comment, an instruction, or a note associated with the statement.

element.name: relevantHistory
element.definition: Key events in the history of the request.
element.comment: This might not include provenances for all versions of the request - only those deemed "relevant" or important. This SHALL NOT include the Provenance associated with this current version of the resource. (If that provenance is deemed to be a "relevant" change, it will need to be added as part of a later update. Until then, it can be queried directly as the Provenance that points to this version using _revinclude All Provenances should have some historical version of this Request as their subject.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Identifiers assigned to this order by the orderer or by the receiver.

element.name: instantiatesCanonical
element.definition: The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this DeviceRequest.
element.comment: Note: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: instantiatesUri
element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this DeviceRequest.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.

element.definition: The request takes the place of the referenced completed or terminated request(s).

element.definition: The status of the request.

binding.description: Codes representing the status of the request.

binding.description: Codes for devices that can be requested.

element.name: encounter
element.definition: An encounter that provides additional context in which this request is made.

element.description: Desired time or schedule for use

binding.description: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care team, such as "Primary physician", "Team coordinator", "Caregiver", etc.

element.definition: Reason or justification for the use of this device.

element.definition: Reason or justification for the use of this device.

element.definition: Insurance plans, coverage extensions, pre-authorizations and/or pre-determinations that may be required for delivering the requested service.

element.definition: Details about this request that were not represented at all or sufficiently in one of the attributes provided in a class. These may include for example a comment, an instruction, or a note associated with the statement.

element.name: relevantHistory
element.definition: Key events in the history of the request.
element.comment: This might not include provenances for all versions of the request - only those deemed "relevant" or important. This SHALL NOT include the Provenance associated with this current version of the resource. (If that provenance is deemed to be a "relevant" change, it will need to be added as part of a later update. Until then, it can be queried directly as the Provenance that points to this version using _revinclude All Provenances should have some historical version of this Request as their subject.

element.name: code
element.definition: A code or string that identifies the device detail being asserted.

binding.name: ParameterCode
binding.description: A code that identifies the device detail.

element.name: value
element.definition: The value of the device detail.
element.comment: Range means device should have a value that falls somewhere within the specified range.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: An external identifier for this statement such as an IRI.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: A plan, proposal or order that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this DeviceUseStatement.

element.name: status
element.definition: A code representing the patient or other source's judgment about the state of the device used that this statement is about. Generally this will be active or completed.
element.comment: DeviceUseStatment is a statement at a point in time. The status is only representative at the point when it was asserted. The value set for contains codes that assert the status of the use by the patient (for example, stopped or on hold) as well as codes that assert the status of the resource itself (for example, entered in error). This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes that mark the statement as not currently valid.

binding.name: DeviceUseStatementStatus
binding.description: A coded concept indicating the current status of the Device Usage.

element.name: subject
element.definition: The patient who used the device.

element.name: derivedFrom
element.definition: Allows linking the DeviceUseStatement to the underlying Request, or to other information that supports or is used to derive the DeviceUseStatement.
element.comment: The most common use cases for deriving a DeviceUseStatement comes from creating it from a request or from an observation or a claim. it should be noted that the amount of information that is available varies from the type resource that you derive the DeviceUseStatement from.

element.name: timing
element.description: How often the device was used
element.definition: How often the device was used.

element.name: recordedOn
element.definition: The time at which the statement was made/recorded.

element.name: source
element.definition: Who reported the device was being used by the patient.

element.name: device
element.definition: The details of the device used.

element.name: reasonCode
element.definition: Reason or justification for the use of the device.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Indicates another resource whose existence justifies this DeviceUseStatement.

element.name: bodySite
element.definition: Indicates the anotomic location on the subject's body where the device was used ( i.e. the target).

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.name: note
element.definition: Details about the device statement that were not represented at all or sufficiently in one of the attributes provided in a class. These may include for example a comment, an instruction, or a note associated with the statement.

element.name: comment
element.definition: A comment about the image. Typically, this is used to provide an explanation for why the image is included, or to draw the viewer's attention to important features.
element.comment: The comment should be displayed with the image. It would be common for the report to include additional discussion of the image contents in other sections such as the conclusion.

element.name: link
element.definition: Reference to the image source.

element.name: valueReference
element.definition: Value of extension - must be one of a constrained set of the data types (see [Extensibility](http://hl7.org/fhir/extensibility.html) for a list).

element.name: locationPerformed
element.definition: Facility location where this report was prepared.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Identifiers assigned to this report by the performer or other systems.
element.comment: Usually assigned by the Information System of the diagnostic service provider (filler id).

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: Details concerning a service requested.
element.comment: Note: Usually there is one test request for each result, however in some circumstances multiple test requests may be represented using a single test result resource. Note that there are also cases where one request leads to multiple reports.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of the diagnostic report.

element.name: category
element.definition: A code that classifies the clinical discipline, department or diagnostic service that created the report (e.g. cardiology, biochemistry, hematology, MRI). This is used for searching, sorting and display purposes.
element.comment: Multiple categories are allowed using various categorization schemes. The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set. More fine-grained filtering can be performed using the metadata and/or terminology hierarchy in DiagnosticReport.code.

binding.name: DiagnosticServiceSection
binding.description: Codes for diagnostic service sections.

element.name: LaboratorySlice
element.definition: A code that classifies the clinical discipline, department or diagnostic service that created the report (e.g. cardiology, biochemistry, hematology, MRI). This is used for searching, sorting and display purposes.
element.comment: Multiple categories are allowed using various categorization schemes. The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set. More fine-grained filtering can be performed using the metadata and/or terminology hierarchy in DiagnosticReport.code.

binding.name: DiagnosticServiceSection
binding.description: Codes for diagnostic service sections.

element.name: code
element.description: US Core Laboratory Report Order Code
element.definition: The test, panel or battery that was ordered.
element.comment: UsageNote= The typical patterns for codes are: 1) a LOINC code either as a translation from a "local" code or as a primary code, or 2) a local code only if no suitable LOINC exists, or 3) both the local and the LOINC translation. Systems SHALL be capable of sending the local code if one exists.

binding.description: LOINC codes

element.name: subject
element.description: The subject of the report - usually, but not always, the patient
element.definition: The subject of the report. Usually, but not always, this is a patient. However, diagnostic services also perform analyses on specimens collected from a variety of other sources.

element.name: encounter
element.description: Health care event when test ordered
element.definition: The healthcare event (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) which this DiagnosticReport is about.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some events may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter (e.g. pre-admission laboratory tests).

element.name: effective
element.definition: This is the Specimen Collection Datetime or Period which is the physically relevent dateTime for laboratory tests.
element.comment: If the diagnostic procedure was performed on the patient, this is the time it was performed. If there are specimens, the diagnostically relevant time can be derived from the specimen collection times, but the specimen information is not always available, and the exact relationship between the specimens and the diagnostically relevant time is not always automatic.

element.name: issued
element.definition: The date and time that this version of the report was made available to providers, typically after the report was reviewed and verified.
element.comment: May be different from the update time of the resource itself, because that is the status of the record (potentially a secondary copy), not the actual release time of the report.

element.name: performer
element.definition: The diagnostic service that is responsible for issuing the report.
element.comment: This is not necessarily the source of the atomic data items or the entity that interpreted the results. It is the entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.

element.name: resultsInterpreter
element.definition: The practitioner or organization that is responsible for the report's conclusions and interpretations.
element.comment: Might not be the same entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.

element.name: specimen
element.description: Specimens this report is based on
element.definition: Details about the specimens on which this diagnostic report is based.
element.comment: If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the test result name, then this additional data may be redundant. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per observation or group.

element.name: result
element.definition: [Observations](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html) that are part of this diagnostic report.
element.comment: Observations can contain observations.

element.name: imagingStudy
element.description: Reference to full details of imaging associated with the diagnostic report
element.definition: One or more links to full details of any imaging performed during the diagnostic investigation. Typically, this is imaging performed by DICOM enabled modalities, but this is not required. A fully enabled PACS viewer can use this information to provide views of the source images.
element.comment: ImagingStudy and the image element are somewhat overlapping - typically, the list of image references in the image element will also be found in one of the imaging study resources. However, each caters to different types of displays for different types of purposes. Neither, either, or both may be provided.

element.name: media
element.description: Key images associated with this report
element.definition: A list of key images associated with this report. The images are generally created during the diagnostic process, and may be directly of the patient, or of treated specimens (i.e. slides of interest).

element.name: conclusion
element.definition: Concise and clinically contextualized summary conclusion (interpretation/impression) of the diagnostic report.

element.name: conclusionCode
element.description: Codes for the clinical conclusion of test results
element.definition: One or more codes that represent the summary conclusion (interpretation/impression) of the diagnostic report.

binding.description: This value set includes all the "Clinical finding" SNOMED CT codes - concepts where concept is-a 404684003 (Clinical finding (finding)).

element.name: presentedForm
element.definition: Rich text representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they SHALL be semantically equivalent.
element.comment: "application/pdf" is recommended as the most reliable and interoperable in this context.

element.name: valueReference
element.definition: Value of extension - must be one of a constrained set of the data types (see [Extensibility](http://hl7.org/fhir/extensibility.html) for a list).

element.name: locationPerformed
element.definition: Facility location where this report was prepared.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Identifiers assigned to this report by the performer or other systems.
element.comment: Usually assigned by the Information System of the diagnostic service provider (filler id).

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: Details concerning a service requested.
element.comment: Note: Usually there is one test request for each result, however in some circumstances multiple test requests may be represented using a single test result resource. Note that there are also cases where one request leads to multiple reports.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of the diagnostic report.

element.name: category
element.definition: A code that classifies the clinical discipline, department or diagnostic service that created the report (e.g. cardiology, biochemistry, hematology, MRI). This is used for searching, sorting and display purposes.
element.comment: Multiple categories are allowed using various categorization schemes. The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set. More fine-grained filtering can be performed using the metadata and/or terminology hierarchy in DiagnosticReport.code.

element.name: code
element.definition: The test, panel, report, or note that was ordered.
element.comment: UsageNote= The typical patterns for codes are: 1) a LOINC code either as a translation from a "local" code or as a primary code, or 2) a local code only if no suitable LOINC exists, or 3) both the local and the LOINC translation. Systems SHALL be capable of sending the local code if one exists.

binding.description: LOINC codes

element.name: subject
element.description: The subject of the report - usually, but not always, the patient
element.definition: The subject of the report. Usually, but not always, this is a patient. However diagnostic services also perform analyses on specimens collected from a variety of other sources.

element.name: encounter
element.description: Health care event when test ordered
element.definition: The healthcare event (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) which this DiagnosticReport is about.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some events may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter (e.g. pre-admission laboratory tests).

element.name: effective
element.description: Time of the report or note
element.definition: This is the Datetime or Period when the report or note was written.
element.comment: If the diagnostic procedure was performed on the patient, this is the time it was performed. If there are specimens, the diagnostically relevant time can be derived from the specimen collection times, but the specimen information is not always available, and the exact relationship between the specimens and the diagnostically relevant time is not always automatic.

element.name: issued
element.definition: The date and time that this version of the report was made available to providers, typically after the report was reviewed and verified.
element.comment: May be different from the update time of the resource itself, because that is the status of the record (potentially a secondary copy), not the actual release time of the report.

element.name: performer
element.definition: The diagnostic service that is responsible for issuing the report.
element.comment: This is not necessarily the source of the atomic data items or the entity that interpreted the results. It is the entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.

element.name: resultsInterpreter
element.definition: The practitioner or organization that is responsible for the report's conclusions and interpretations.
element.comment: Might not be the same entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.

element.name: specimen
element.description: Specimens this report is based on
element.definition: Details about the specimens on which this diagnostic report is based.
element.comment: If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the test result name, then this additional data may be redundant. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per observation or group.

element.name: result
element.definition: [Observations](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html) that are part of this diagnostic report.
element.comment: Observations can contain observations.

element.name: imagingStudy
element.description: Reference to full details of imaging associated with the diagnostic report
element.definition: One or more links to full details of any imaging performed during the diagnostic investigation. Typically, this is imaging performed by DICOM enabled modalities, but this is not required. A fully enabled PACS viewer can use this information to provide views of the source images.
element.comment: ImagingStudy and the image element are somewhat overlapping - typically, the list of image references in the image element will also be found in one of the imaging study resources. However, each caters to different types of displays for different types of purposes. Neither, either, or both may be provided.

element.name: media
element.description: Key images associated with this report
element.definition: A list of key images associated with this report. The images are generally created during the diagnostic process, and may be directly of the patient, or of treated specimens (i.e. slides of interest).

element.name: conclusion
element.definition: Concise and clinically contextualized summary conclusion (interpretation/impression) of the diagnostic report.

element.name: conclusionCode
element.description: Codes for the clinical conclusion of test results
element.definition: One or more codes that represent the summary conclusion (interpretation/impression) of the diagnostic report.

binding.description: This value set includes all the "Clinical finding" SNOMED CT codes - concepts where concept is-a 404684003 (Clinical finding (finding)).

element.name: presentedForm
element.definition: Rich text representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they SHALL be semantically equivalent.
element.comment: "application/pdf" is recommended as the most reliable and interoperable in this context.

element.name: text
element.description: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative.
