Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied). This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

element.name: contained
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.name: extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: modifierExtension
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: sequence
element.description: The order of the dosage instructions
element.definition: Indicates the order in which the dosage instructions should be applied or interpreted.

element.name: text
element.description: Free text dosage instructions e.g. SIG
element.definition: Free text dosage instructions e.g. SIG.

element.name: additionalInstruction
element.description: Supplemental instruction or warnings to the patient - e.g. "with meals", "may cause drowsiness"
element.definition: Supplemental instructions to the patient on how to take the medication (e.g. "with meals" or"take half to one hour before food") or warnings for the patient about the medication (e.g. "may cause drowsiness" or "avoid exposure of skin to direct sunlight or sunlamps").
element.comment: Information about administration or preparation of the medication (e.g. "infuse as rapidly as possibly via intraperitoneal port" or "immediately following drug x") should be populated in dosage.text.

binding.name: AdditionalInstruction
binding.description: A coded concept identifying additional instructions such as "take with water" or "avoid operating heavy machinery".

element.name: patientInstruction
element.definition: Instructions in terms that are understood by the patient or consumer.

element.name: timing
element.definition: When medication should be administered.
element.comment: This attribute might not always be populated while the Dosage.text is expected to be populated. If both are populated, then the Dosage.text should reflect the content of the Dosage.timing.

element.name: asNeeded
element.definition: Indicates whether the Medication is only taken when needed within a specific dosing schedule (Boolean option), or it indicates the precondition for taking the Medication (CodeableConcept).
element.comment: Can express "as needed" without a reason by setting the Boolean = True. In this case the CodeableConcept is not populated. Or you can express "as needed" with a reason by including the CodeableConcept. In this case the Boolean is assumed to be True. If you set the Boolean to False, then the dose is given according to the schedule and is not "prn" or "as needed".

binding.name: MedicationAsNeededReason
binding.description: A coded concept identifying the precondition that should be met or evaluated prior to consuming or administering a medication dose. For example "pain", "30 minutes prior to sexual intercourse", "on flare-up" etc.

element.name: site
element.definition: Body site to administer to.
element.comment: If the use case requires attributes from the BodySite resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [bodySite](extension-bodysite.html). May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.

binding.name: MedicationAdministrationSite
binding.description: A coded concept describing the site location the medicine enters into or onto the body.

element.name: route
element.definition: How drug should enter body.

binding.name: RouteOfAdministration
binding.description: A coded concept describing the route or physiological path of administration of a therapeutic agent into or onto the body of a subject.

element.name: method
element.definition: Technique for administering medication.
element.comment: Terminologies used often pre-coordinate this term with the route and or form of administration.

binding.name: MedicationAdministrationMethod
binding.description: A coded concept describing the technique by which the medicine is administered.

element.name: doseAndRate
element.definition: The amount of medication administered.

element.name: maxDosePerPeriod
element.description: Upper limit on medication per unit of time
element.definition: Upper limit on medication per unit of time.
element.comment: This is intended for use as an adjunct to the dosage when there is an upper cap. For example "2 tablets every 4 hours to a maximum of 8/day".

element.name: maxDosePerAdministration
element.description: Upper limit on medication per administration
element.definition: Upper limit on medication per administration.
element.comment: This is intended for use as an adjunct to the dosage when there is an upper cap. For example, a body surface area related dose with a maximum amount, such as 1.5 mg/m2 (maximum 2 mg) IV over 5 – 10 minutes would have doseQuantity of 1.5 mg/m2 and maxDosePerAdministration of 2 mg.

element.name: maxDosePerLifetime
element.description: Upper limit on medication per lifetime of the patient
element.definition: Upper limit on medication per lifetime of the patient.

element.name: type
element.description: The kind of dose or rate specified
element.definition: The kind of dose or rate specified, for example, ordered or calculated.

binding.name: DoseAndRateType
binding.description: The kind of dose or rate specified.

element.name: dose
element.definition: Amount of medication per dose.
element.comment: Note that this specifies the quantity of the specified medication, not the quantity for each active ingredient(s). Each ingredient amount can be communicated in the Medication resource. For example, if one wants to communicate that a tablet was 375 mg, where the dose was one tablet, you can use the Medication resource to document that the tablet was comprised of 375 mg of drug XYZ. Alternatively if the dose was 375 mg, then you may only need to use the Medication resource to indicate this was a tablet. If the example were an IV such as dopamine and you wanted to communicate that 400mg of dopamine was mixed in 500 ml of some IV solution, then this would all be communicated in the Medication resource. If the administration is not intended to be instantaneous (rate is present or timing has a duration), this can be specified to convey the total amount to be administered over the period of time as indicated by the schedule e.g. 500 ml in dose, with timing used to convey that this should be done over 4 hours.

element.name: rate
element.description: Amount of medication per unit of time
element.definition: Amount of medication per unit of time.
element.comment: It is possible to supply both a rate and a doseQuantity to provide full details about how the medication is to be administered and supplied. If the rate is intended to change over time, depending on local rules/regulations, each change should be captured as a new version of the MedicationRequest with an updated rate, or captured with a new MedicationRequest with the new rate. It is possible to specify a rate over time (for example, 100 ml/hour) using either the rateRatio and rateQuantity. The rateQuantity approach requires systems to have the capability to parse UCUM grammer where ml/hour is included rather than a specific ratio where the time is specified as the denominator. Where a rate such as 500ml over 2 hours is specified, the use of rateRatio may be more semantically correct than specifying using a rateQuantity of 250 mg/hour.

element.name: id
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.name: extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: statusReason
element.definition: Captures the reason for the current state of the resource.
element.comment: This is generally only used for "exception" statuses such as "suspended" or "cancelled". The reason for performing the request at all is captured in reasonCode, not here. (Distinct reason codes for different statuses can be enforced using invariants if they are universal bindings).

element.name: procedure
element.definition: Procedures performed during the encounter, or as the primary reason for the encounter.

element.name: identifier
element.description: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known
element.definition: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known.

element.name: status
element.description: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
element.definition: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +.
element.comment: Note that internal business rules will determine the appropriate transitions that may occur between statuses (and also classes).

binding.name: EncounterStatus
binding.description: Current state of the encounter.

element.name: statusHistory
element.definition: The status history permits the encounter resource to contain the status history without needing to read through the historical versions of the resource, or even have the server store them.
element.comment: The current status is always found in the current version of the resource, not the status history.

element.name: class
element.definition: Concepts representing classification of patient encounter such as ambulatory (outpatient), inpatient, emergency, home health or others due to local variations.

binding.name: EncounterClass
binding.description: Classification of the encounter.

element.name: classHistory
element.definition: The class history permits the tracking of the encounters transitions without needing to go through the resource history. This would be used for a case where an admission starts of as an emergency encounter, then transitions into an inpatient scenario. Doing this and not restarting a new encounter ensures that any lab/diagnostic results can more easily follow the patient and not require re-processing and not get lost or cancelled during a kind of discharge from emergency to inpatient.

element.name: type
element.definition: Specific type of encounter (e.g. e-mail consultation, surgical day-care, skilled nursing, rehabilitation).
element.comment: Since there are many ways to further classify encounters, this element is 0..*.

binding.description: Valueset to describe the Encounter Type

element.name: serviceType
element.definition: Broad categorization of the service that is to be provided (e.g. cardiology).

binding.name: EncounterServiceType
binding.description: Broad categorization of the service that is to be provided.

element.name: priority
element.description: Indicates the urgency of the encounter
element.definition: Indicates the urgency of the encounter.

binding.description: The priority of the encounter (e.g., Urgent, Normal, etc.)

element.name: subject
element.description: The patient or group present at the encounter
element.definition: The patient or group present at the encounter.
element.comment: While the encounter is always about the patient, the patient might not actually be known in all contexts of use, and there may be a group of patients that could be anonymous (such as in a group therapy for Alcoholics Anonymous - where the recording of the encounter could be used for billing on the number of people/staff and not important to the context of the specific patients) or alternately in veterinary care a herd of sheep receiving treatment (where the animals are not individually tracked).

element.name: episodeOfCare
element.description: Episode(s) of care that this encounter should be recorded against
element.definition: Where a specific encounter should be classified as a part of a specific episode(s) of care this field should be used. This association can facilitate grouping of related encounters together for a specific purpose, such as government reporting, issue tracking, association via a common problem. The association is recorded on the encounter as these are typically created after the episode of care and grouped on entry rather than editing the episode of care to append another encounter to it (the episode of care could span years).

element.name: basedOn
element.description: The ServiceRequest that initiated this encounter
element.definition: The request this encounter satisfies (e.g. incoming referral or procedure request).

element.name: participant
element.description: List of participants involved in the encounter
element.definition: The list of people responsible for providing the service.

element.name: appointment
element.description: The appointment that scheduled this encounter
element.definition: The appointment that scheduled this encounter.

element.name: period
element.description: The start and end time of the encounter
element.definition: The start and end time of the encounter.
element.comment: If not (yet) known, the end of the Period may be omitted.

element.name: length
element.description: Quantity of time the encounter lasted (less time absent)
element.definition: Quantity of time the encounter lasted. This excludes the time during leaves of absence.
element.comment: May differ from the time the Encounter.period lasted because of leave of absence.

element.name: reasonCode
element.description: Coded reason the encounter takes place
element.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
element.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

binding.name: EncounterReason
binding.description: Reason why the encounter takes place.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
element.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

element.name: diagnosis
element.description: The list of diagnosis relevant to this encounter
element.definition: The list of diagnosis relevant to this encounter.

element.name: account
element.description: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this Encounter
element.definition: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this Encounter.
element.comment: The billing system may choose to allocate billable items associated with the Encounter to different referenced Accounts based on internal business rules.

element.name: hospitalization
element.description: Details about the admission to a healthcare service
element.definition: Details about the admission to a healthcare service.
element.comment: An Encounter may cover more than just the inpatient stay. Contexts such as outpatients, community clinics, and aged care facilities are also included. The duration recorded in the period of this encounter covers the entire scope of this hospitalization record.

element.name: location
element.description: List of locations where the patient has been
element.definition: List of locations where the patient has been during this encounter.
element.comment: Virtual encounters can be recorded in the Encounter by specifying a location reference to a location of type "kind" such as "client's home" and an encounter.class = "virtual".

element.name: serviceProvider
element.description: The organization (facility) responsible for this encounter
element.definition: The organization that is primarily responsible for this Encounter's services. This MAY be the same as the organization on the Patient record, however it could be different, such as if the actor performing the services was from an external organization (which may be billed seperately) for an external consultation. Refer to the example bundle showing an abbreviated set of Encounters for a colonoscopy.

element.name: partOf
element.description: Another Encounter this encounter is part of
element.definition: Another Encounter of which this encounter is a part of (administratively or in time).
element.comment: This is also used for associating a child's encounter back to the mother's encounter. Refer to the Notes section in the Patient resource for further details.

element.name: class
element.definition: inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +.

binding.name: EncounterClass
binding.description: Classification of the encounter.

element.name: period
element.description: The time that the episode was in the specified class
element.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified class.

element.name: condition
element.description: The diagnosis or procedure relevant to the encounter
element.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, as specified using information from another resource. For admissions, this is the admission diagnosis. The indication will typically be a Condition (with other resources referenced in the evidence.detail), or a Procedure.
element.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

element.name: use
element.description: Role that this diagnosis has within the encounter (e.g. admission, billing, discharge …)
element.definition: Role that this diagnosis has within the encounter (e.g. admission, billing, discharge …).

binding.name: DiagnosisRole
binding.description: The type of diagnosis this condition represents.

element.name: rank
element.description: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type)
element.definition: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type).

element.name: diagnosisPresentOnAdmission
element.definition: Indicator of whether the Encounter diagnosis was present at the time of admission.

element.name: preAdmissionIdentifier
element.definition: Pre-admission identifier.

element.name: origin
element.description: The location/organization from which the patient came before admission
element.definition: The location/organization from which the patient came before admission.

element.name: admitSource
element.description: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer)
element.definition: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer).

binding.name: AdmitSource
binding.description: From where the patient was admitted.

element.name: reAdmission
element.description: The type of hospital re-admission that has occurred (if any). If the value is absent, then this is not identified as a readmission
element.definition: Whether this hospitalization is a readmission and why if known.

binding.name: ReAdmissionType
binding.description: The reason for re-admission of this hospitalization encounter.

element.name: dietPreference
element.description: Diet preferences reported by the patient
element.definition: Diet preferences reported by the patient.
element.comment: For example, a patient may request both a dairy-free and nut-free diet preference (not mutually exclusive).

binding.name: PatientDiet
binding.description: Medical, cultural or ethical food preferences to help with catering requirements.

element.name: specialCourtesy
element.definition: Special courtesies (VIP, board member).

binding.name: Courtesies
binding.description: Special courtesies.

element.name: specialArrangement
element.definition: Any special requests that have been made for this hospitalization encounter, such as the provision of specific equipment or other things.

binding.name: Arrangements
binding.description: Special arrangements.

element.name: destination
element.description: Location/organization to which the patient is discharged
element.definition: Location/organization to which the patient is discharged.

element.name: dischargeDisposition
element.description: Category or kind of location after discharge
element.definition: Category or kind of location after discharge.

binding.name: DischargeDisp
binding.description: Discharge Disposition.

element.name: location
element.definition: The location where the encounter takes place.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of the participants' presence at the specified location during the period specified. If the participant is no longer at the location, then the period will have an end date/time.
element.comment: When the patient is no longer active at a location, then the period end date is entered, and the status may be changed to completed.

binding.name: EncounterLocationStatus
binding.description: The status of the location.

element.name: physicalType
element.description: The physical type of the location (usually the level in the location hierachy - bed room ward etc.)
element.definition: This will be used to specify the required levels (bed/ward/room/etc.) desired to be recorded to simplify either messaging or query.
element.comment:
This information is de-normalized from the Location resource to support the easier understanding of the encounter resource and processing in messaging or query.
There may be many levels in the hierachy, and this may only pic specific levels that are required for a specific usage scenario.

binding.name: PhysicalType
binding.description: Physical form of the location.

element.name: period
element.description: Time period during which the patient was present at the location
element.definition: Time period during which the patient was present at the location.

element.name: type
element.definition: Role of participant in encounter.
element.comment: The participant type indicates how an individual participates in an encounter. It includes non-practitioner participants, and for practitioners this is to describe the action type in the context of this encounter (e.g. Admitting Dr, Attending Dr, Translator, Consulting Dr). This is different to the practitioner roles which are functional roles, derived from terms of employment, education, licensing, etc.

binding.name: ParticipantType
binding.description: Role of participant in encounter.

element.name: period
element.description: Period of time during the encounter that the participant participated
element.definition: The period of time that the specified participant participated in the encounter. These can overlap or be sub-sets of the overall encounter's period.

element.name: individual
element.description: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient
element.definition: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient.
element.comment: Should include QICore-RelatedPerson as a possible participant, but USCore-Encounter only allows USCore-Practitioner.

element.name: status
element.description: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
element.definition: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +.

binding.name: EncounterStatus
binding.description: Current state of the encounter.

element.name: period
element.description: The time that the episode was in the specified status
element.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified status.

element.name: type
element.definition: Whether the procedure was primary or secondary.

element.name: rank
element.definition: The ranking of the procedure within the encounter.

element.name: procedure
element.definition: A reference to the procedure that was performed.

element.name: url
element.description: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comment: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition SHALL be a URI for the Structure Definition defining the extension.

element.name: description
element.description: Natural language description of the condition
element.definition: A brief, natural language description of the condition that effectively communicates the intended semantics.

element.name: name
element.description: Short name assigned to expression for reuse
element.definition: A short name assigned to the expression to allow for multiple reuse of the expression in the context where it is defined.

element.name: language
element.definition: The media type of the language for the expression.

binding.name: ExpressionLanguage
binding.description: The media type of the expression language.

element.name: expression
element.definition: An expression in the specified language that returns a value.

element.name: reference
element.definition: A URI that defines where the expression is found.
element.comment: If both a reference and an expression is found, the reference SHALL point to the same expression.

element.name: url
element.description: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comment: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition SHALL be a URI for the Structure Definition defining the extension.

element.name: value
element.definition: Value of extension - must be one of a constrained set of the data types (see [Extensibility](extensibility.html) for a list).

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this family member history by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: instantiatesCanonical
element.definition: The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this FamilyMemberHistory.

element.name: instantiatesUri
element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this FamilyMemberHistory.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.

element.name: status
element.definition: A code specifying the status of the record of the family history of a specific family member.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.name: FamilyHistoryStatus
binding.description: A code that identifies the status of the family history record.

element.name: dataAbsentReason
element.definition: Describes why the family member's history is not available.

binding.name: FamilyHistoryAbsentReason
binding.description: Codes describing the reason why a family member's history is not available.

element.name: patient
element.definition: The person who this history concerns.

element.name: date
element.description: When history was recorded or last updated
element.definition: The date (and possibly time) when the family member history was recorded or last updated.
element.comment: This should be captured even if the same as the date on the List aggregating the full family history.

element.name: name
element.definition: This will either be a name or a description; e.g. "Aunt Susan", "my cousin with the red hair".

element.name: relationship
element.definition: The type of relationship this person has to the patient (father, mother, brother etc.).

binding.name: FamilialRelationship
binding.description: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the related person being described in the family member history.

element.name: sex
element.definition: The birth sex of the family member.
element.comment: This element should ideally reflect whether the individual is genetically male or female. However, as reported information based on the knowledge of the patient or reporting friend/relative, there may be situations where the reported sex might not be totally accurate. E.g. 'Aunt Sue' might be XY rather than XX. Questions soliciting this information should be phrased to encourage capture of genetic sex where known. However, systems performing analysis should also allow for the possibility of imprecision with this element.

binding.name: Sex
binding.description: Codes describing the sex assigned at birth as documented on the birth registration.

element.name: born
element.definition: The actual or approximate date of birth of the relative.

element.name: age
element.definition: The age of the relative at the time the family member history is recorded.
element.comment: use estimatedAge to indicate whether the age is actual or not.

element.name: estimatedAge
element.definition: If true, indicates that the age value specified is an estimated value.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the fact that age is estimated can/should change the results of any algorithm that calculates based on the specified age.

element.name: deceased
element.definition: Deceased flag or the actual or approximate age of the relative at the time of death for the family member history record.

element.name: reasonCode
element.description: Why was family member history performed?
element.definition: Describes why the family member history occurred in coded or textual form.
element.comment: Textual reasons can be captured using reasonCode.text.

binding.name: FamilyHistoryReason
binding.description: Codes indicating why the family member history was done.

element.name: reasonReference
element.description: Why was family member history performed?
element.definition: Indicates a Condition, Observation, AllergyIntolerance, or QuestionnaireResponse that justifies this family member history event.

element.name: note
element.definition: This property allows a non condition-specific note to the made about the related person. Ideally, the note would be in the condition property, but this is not always possible.

element.name: condition
element.description: Condition that the related person had
element.definition: The significant Conditions (or condition) that the family member had. This is a repeating section to allow a system to represent more than one condition per resource, though there is nothing stopping multiple resources - one per condition.

element.name: code
element.definition: The actual condition specified. Could be a coded condition (like MI or Diabetes) or a less specific string like 'cancer' depending on how much is known about the condition and the capabilities of the creating system.

binding.name: ConditionCode
binding.description: Identification of the Condition or diagnosis.

element.name: outcome
element.definition: Indicates what happened following the condition. If the condition resulted in death, deceased date is captured on the relation.

binding.name: ConditionOutcome
binding.description: The result of the condition for the patient; e.g. death, permanent disability, temporary disability, etc.

element.name: contributedToDeath
element.description: Whether the condition contributed to the cause of death
element.definition: This condition contributed to the cause of death of the related person. If contributedToDeath is not populated, then it is unknown.

element.name: onset
element.definition: Either the age of onset, range of approximate age or descriptive string can be recorded. For conditions with multiple occurrences, this describes the first known occurrence.

element.name: note
element.definition: An area where general notes can be placed about this specific condition.

element.name: condition-abatement
element.description: When (or if) the family member's condition resolved
element.definition: The approximate date, age, or flag indicating that the condition of the family member resolved. The abatement should only be specified if the condition is stated in the positive sense, i.e., the didNotHave flag is false.

element.name: condition-severity
element.description: The seriousness of the family member condition
element.definition: A qualification of the seriousness or impact on health of the family member condition.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this flag by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: status
element.definition: Supports basic workflow.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.name: FlagStatus
binding.description: Indicates whether this flag is active and needs to be displayed to a user, or whether it is no longer needed or was entered in error.

element.name: category
element.definition: Allows a flag to be divided into different categories like clinical, administrative etc. Intended to be used as a means of filtering which flags are displayed to particular user or in a given context.
element.comment: The value set will often need to be adjusted based on local business rules and usage context.

binding.name: FlagCategory
binding.description: A general category for flags for filtering/display purposes.

element.name: code
element.description: Coded or textual message to display to user
element.definition: The coded value or textual component of the flag to display to the user.
element.comment: If non-coded, use CodeableConcept.text. This element should always be included in the narrative.

binding.name: FlagCode
binding.description: Detail codes identifying specific flagged issues.

element.name: subject
element.definition: The patient, location, group, organization, or practitioner etc. this is about record this flag is associated with.

element.name: period
element.description: Time period when flag is active
element.definition: The period of time from the activation of the flag to inactivation of the flag. If the flag is active, the end of the period should be unspecified.

element.name: encounter
element.definition: This alert is only relevant during the encounter.
element.comment: If both Flag.encounter and Flag.period are valued, then Flag.period.start shall not be before Encounter.period.start and Flag.period.end shall not be after Encounter.period.end.

element.name: author
element.definition: The person, organization or device that created the flag.

element.name: reasonRejected
element.description: The reason the goal was not accepted
element.definition: The reason the goal was not accepted. Applies only if the status of the goal is rejected.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this goal by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: lifecycleStatus
element.description: proposed | planned | accepted | active | on-hold | completed | cancelled | entered-in-error | rejected
element.definition: The state of the goal throughout its lifecycle.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the lifecycleStatus contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

element.name: achievementStatus
element.description: in-progress | improving | worsening | no-change | achieved | sustaining | not-achieved | no-progress | not-attainable
element.definition: Describes the progression, or lack thereof, towards the goal against the target.

binding.name: GoalAchievementStatus
binding.description: Indicates the progression, or lack thereof, towards the goal against the target.

element.name: category
element.definition: Indicates a category the goal falls within.

binding.name: GoalCategory
binding.description: Codes for grouping and sorting goals.

element.name: priority
element.definition: Identifies the mutually agreed level of importance associated with reaching/sustaining the goal.
element.comment: Extensions are available to track priorities as established by each participant (i.e. Priority from the patient's perspective, different practitioners' perspectives, family member's perspectives) The ordinal extension on Coding can be used to convey a numerically comparable ranking to priority. (Keep in mind that different coding systems may use a "low value=important".

binding.name: GoalPriority
binding.description: The level of importance associated with a goal.

element.name: description
element.definition: Human-readable and/or coded description of a specific desired objective of care, such as "control blood pressure" or "negotiate an obstacle course" or "dance with child at wedding".
element.comment: If no code is available, use CodeableConcept.text.

binding.description: This value set includes all the "Clinical finding" SNOMED CT codes - concepts where concept is-a 404684003 (Clinical finding (finding)).

element.name: subject
element.description: Who this goal is intended for
element.definition: Identifies the patient, group or organization for whom the goal is being established.
element.comment: Should include QICore-Organization, but the base profile only allows USCore-Patient derivatives.

element.name: start
element.definition: The date or event after which the goal should begin being pursued.

element.name: target
element.definition: Indicates what should be done by when.
element.comment: When multiple targets are present for a single goal instance, all targets must be met for the overall goal to be met.

constraint.name: gol-1
constraint.message: Goal.target.measure is required if Goal.target.detail is populated

element.name: statusDate
element.definition: Identifies when the current status. I.e. When initially created, when achieved, when cancelled, etc.
element.comment: To see the date for past statuses, query history.

element.name: statusReason
element.definition: Captures the reason for the current status.
element.comment: This will typically be captured for statuses such as rejected, on-hold or cancelled, but could be present for others.

element.name: expressedBy
element.definition: Indicates whose goal this is - patient goal, practitioner goal, etc.
element.comment: This is the individual responsible for establishing the goal, not necessarily who recorded it. (For that, use the Provenance resource.).

element.name: addresses
element.definition: The identified conditions and other health record elements that are intended to be addressed by the goal.

element.name: note
element.definition: Any comments related to the goal.
element.comment: May be used for progress notes, concerns or other related information that doesn't actually describe the goal itself.

element.name: outcomeCode
element.description: What result was achieved regarding the goal?
element.definition: Identifies the change (or lack of change) at the point when the status of the goal is assessed.
element.comment: Note that this should not duplicate the goal status.

binding.name: GoalOutcome
binding.description: The result of the goal; e.g. "25% increase in shoulder mobility", "Anxiety reduced to moderate levels". "15 kg weight loss sustained over 6 months".

element.name: outcomeReference
element.definition: Details of what's changed (or not changed).
element.comment: The goal outcome is independent of the outcome of the related activities. For example, if the Goal is to achieve a target body weight of 150 lb and a care plan activity is defined to diet, then the care plan’s activity outcome could be calories consumed whereas goal outcome is an observation for the actual body weight measured.

element.name: measure
element.description: The parameter whose value is being tracked
element.definition: The parameter whose value is being tracked, e.g. body weight, blood pressure, or hemoglobin A1c level.

binding.description: LOINC codes

element.name: detail
element.description: The target value to be achieved
element.definition: The target value of the focus to be achieved to signify the fulfillment of the goal, e.g. 150 pounds, 7.0%. Either the high or low or both values of the range can be specified. When a low value is missing, it indicates that the goal is achieved at any focus value at or below the high value. Similarly, if the high value is missing, it indicates that the goal is achieved at any focus value at or above the low value.
element.comment: A CodeableConcept with just a text would be used instead of a string if the field was usually coded, or if the type associated with the Goal.target.measure defines a coded value.

binding.name: GoalTargetDetail
binding.description: Codes to identify the target value of the focus to be achieved to signify the fulfillment of the goal.

element.name: due
element.definition: Indicates either the date or the duration after start by which the goal should be met.

element.name: use
element.description: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for this name.
element.comment: Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.

binding.name: NameUse
binding.description: The use of a human name.

element.name: text
element.description: Text representation of the full name
element.definition: Specifies the entire name as it should be displayed e.g. on an application UI. This may be provided instead of or as well as the specific parts.
element.comment: Can provide both a text representation and parts. Applications updating a name SHALL ensure that when both text and parts are present, no content is included in the text that isn't found in a part.

element.name: family
element.definition: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
element.comment: Family Name may be decomposed into specific parts using extensions (de, nl, es related cultures).

element.name: given
element.description: Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names
element.definition: Given name.
element.comment: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name parts. Initials may be separated into multiple given names but often aren't due to paractical limitations. This element is not called "first name" since given names do not always come first.

element.name: prefix
element.description: Parts that come before the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.

element.name: suffix
element.description: Parts that come after the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.

element.name: period
element.description: Time period when name was/is in use
element.definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.

element.name: use
element.description: usual | official | temp | secondary | old (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comment: Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.

binding.name: IdentifierUse
binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .

element.name: type
element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comment: This element deals only with general categories of identifiers. It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage. Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.

binding.name: IdentifierType
binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

element.name: system
element.description: The namespace for the identifier value
element.definition: Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
element.comment: Identifier.system is always case sensitive.

element.name: value
element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comment: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986. The value's primary purpose is computational mapping. As a result, it may be normalized for comparison purposes (e.g. removing non-significant whitespace, dashes, etc.) A value formatted for human display can be conveyed using the [Rendered Value extension](extension-rendered-value.html). Identifier.value is to be treated as case sensitive unless knowledge of the Identifier.system allows the processer to be confident that non-case-sensitive processing is safe.

element.name: period
element.description: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

element.name: assigner
element.description: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comment: The Identifier.assigner may omit the .reference element and only contain a .display element reflecting the name or other textual information about the assigning organization.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Identifiers for the ImagingStudy such as DICOM Study Instance UID, and Accession Number.
element.comment: See discussion under [Imaging Study Implementation Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/imagingstudy.html#notes) for encoding of DICOM Study Instance UID. Accession Number should use ACSN Identifier type.

element.name: status
element.definition: The current state of the ImagingStudy.
element.comment: Unknown does not represent "other" - one of the defined statuses must apply. Unknown is used when the authoring system is not sure what the current status is.

binding.name: ImagingStudyStatus
binding.description: The status of the ImagingStudy.

element.name: modality
element.description: All series modality if actual acquisition modalities
element.definition: A list of all the series.modality values that are actual acquisition modalities, i.e. those in the DICOM Context Group 29 (value set OID 1.2.840.10008.6.1.19).

binding.name: ImagingModality
binding.description: Type of acquired data in the instance.

element.name: subject
element.description: Who or what is the subject of the study
element.definition: The subject, typically a patient, of the imaging study.
element.comment: QA phantoms can be recorded with a Device; multiple subjects (such as mice) can be recorded with a Group.

element.name: encounter
element.description: Encounter with which this imaging study is associated
element.definition: The healthcare event (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this ImagingStudy is made.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some events may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter (e.g. pre-admission test).

element.name: started
element.definition: Date and time the study started.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: A list of the diagnostic requests that resulted in this imaging study being performed.

element.name: referrer
element.definition: The requesting/referring physician.

element.name: interpreter
element.definition: Who read the study and interpreted the images or other content.

element.name: endpoint
element.definition: The network service providing access (e.g., query, view, or retrieval) for the study. See implementation notes for information about using DICOM endpoints. A study-level endpoint applies to each series in the study, unless overridden by a series-level endpoint with the same Endpoint.connectionType.
element.comment: Typical endpoint types include DICOM WADO-RS, which is used to retrieve DICOM instances in native or rendered (e.g., JPG, PNG), formats using a RESTful API; DICOM WADO-URI, which can similarly retrieve native or rendered instances, except using an HTTP query-based approach; DICOM QIDO-RS, which allows RESTful query for DICOM information without retrieving the actual instances; or IHE Invoke Image Display (IID), which provides standard invocation of an imaging web viewer.

element.name: numberOfSeries
element.definition: Number of Series in the Study. This value given may be larger than the number of series elements this Resource contains due to resource availability, security, or other factors. This element should be present if any series elements are present.

element.name: numberOfInstances
element.definition: Number of SOP Instances in Study. This value given may be larger than the number of instance elements this resource contains due to resource availability, security, or other factors. This element should be present if any instance elements are present.

element.name: procedureReference
element.definition: The procedure which this ImagingStudy was part of.

element.name: procedureCode
element.definition: The code for the performed procedure type.

binding.name: ImagingProcedureCode
binding.description: The performed procedure type.

element.name: location
element.definition: The principal physical location where the ImagingStudy was performed.

element.name: reasonCode
element.definition: Description of clinical condition indicating why the ImagingStudy was requested.

binding.name: ImagingReason
binding.description: The reason for the study.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Indicates another resource whose existence justifies this Study.

element.name: note
element.definition: Per the recommended DICOM mapping, this element is derived from the Study Description attribute (0008,1030). Observations or findings about the imaging study should be recorded in another resource, e.g. Observation, and not in this element.

element.name: description
element.definition: The Imaging Manager description of the study. Institution-generated description or classification of the Study (component) performed.

element.name: series
element.description: Each study has one or more series of instances
element.definition: Each study has one or more series of images or other content.

element.name: uid
element.description: DICOM Series Instance UID for the series
element.definition: The DICOM Series Instance UID for the series.
element.comment: See [DICOM PS3.3 C.7.3](http://dicom.nema.org/medical/dicom/current/output/chtml/part03/sect_C.7.3.html).

element.name: number
element.definition: The numeric identifier of this series in the study.

element.name: modality
element.description: The modality of the instances in the series
element.definition: The modality of this series sequence.

binding.name: ImagingModality
binding.description: Type of acquired data in the instance.

element.name: description
element.description: A short human readable summary of the series
element.definition: A description of the series.

element.name: numberOfInstances
element.definition: Number of SOP Instances in the Study. The value given may be larger than the number of instance elements this resource contains due to resource availability, security, or other factors. This element should be present if any instance elements are present.

element.name: endpoint
element.definition: The network service providing access (e.g., query, view, or retrieval) for this series. See implementation notes for information about using DICOM endpoints. A series-level endpoint, if present, has precedence over a study-level endpoint with the same Endpoint.connectionType.
element.comment: Typical endpoint types include DICOM WADO-RS, which is used to retrieve DICOM instances in native or rendered (e.g., JPG, PNG) formats using a RESTful API; DICOM WADO-URI, which can similarly retrieve native or rendered instances, except using an HTTP query-based approach; and DICOM QIDO-RS, which allows RESTful query for DICOM information without retrieving the actual instances.

element.name: bodySite
element.definition: The anatomic structures examined. See DICOM Part 16 Annex L (http://dicom.nema.org/medical/dicom/current/output/chtml/part16/chapter_L.html) for DICOM to SNOMED-CT mappings. The bodySite may indicate the laterality of body part imaged; if so, it shall be consistent with any content of ImagingStudy.series.laterality.

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.name: laterality
element.definition: The laterality of the (possibly paired) anatomic structures examined. E.g., the left knee, both lungs, or unpaired abdomen. If present, shall be consistent with any laterality information indicated in ImagingStudy.series.bodySite.

binding.name: Laterality
binding.description: Codes describing body site laterality (left, right, etc.).

element.name: specimen
element.definition: The specimen imaged, e.g., for whole slide imaging of a biopsy.

element.name: started
element.definition: The date and time the series was started.

element.name: performer
element.definition: Indicates who or what performed the series and how they were involved.
element.comment: If the person who performed the series is not known, their Organization may be recorded. A patient, or related person, may be the performer, e.g. for patient-captured images.

element.name: instance
element.description: A single SOP instance from the series
element.definition: A single SOP instance within the series, e.g. an image, or presentation state.

element.name: uid
element.definition: The DICOM SOP Instance UID for this image or other DICOM content.
element.comment: See [DICOM PS3.3 C.12.1](http://dicom.nema.org/medical/dicom/current/output/chtml/part03/sect_C.12.html#sect_C.12.1).

element.name: sopClass
element.definition: DICOM instance type.

binding.name: sopClass
binding.description: The sopClass for the instance.

element.name: number
element.description: The number of this instance in the series
element.definition: The number of instance in the series.

element.name: title
element.definition: The description of the instance.
element.comment: Particularly for post-acquisition analytic objects, such as SR, presentation states, value mapping, etc.

element.name: function
element.definition: Distinguishes the type of involvement of the performer in the series.

binding.name: EventPerformerFunction
binding.description: The type of involvement of the performer.

element.name: actor
element.definition: Indicates who or what performed the series.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: A unique identifier assigned to this immunization record.

element.name: status
element.definition: Indicates the current status of the immunization event.
element.comment: Will generally be set to show that the immunization has been completed or not done. This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.description: Constrained list of immunizaiotn status

element.name: statusReason
element.definition: Indicates the reason the immunization event was not performed.
element.comment: This is generally only used for the status of "not-done". The reason for performing the immunization event is captured in reasonCode, not here.

element.name: vaccineCode
element.definition: Vaccine that was administered or was to be administered.

binding.description: The CVX (vaccine administered) code system

constraint.name: us-core-1
constraint.message: SHOULD have a translation to the NDC value set

element.name: patient
element.definition: The patient who either received or did not receive the immunization.

element.name: encounter
element.definition: The visit or admission or other contact between patient and health care provider the immunization was performed as part of.

element.name: occurrence
element.definition: Date vaccine administered or was to be administered.
element.comment: When immunizations are given a specific date and time should always be known. When immunizations are patient reported, a specific date might not be known. Although partial dates are allowed, an adult patient might not be able to recall the year a childhood immunization was given. An exact date is always preferable, but the use of the String data type is acceptable when an exact date is not known. A small number of vaccines (e.g. live oral typhoid vaccine) are given as a series of patient self-administered dose over a span of time. In cases like this, often, only the first dose (typically a provider supervised dose) is recorded with the occurrence indicating the date/time of the first dose.

element.name: recorded
element.description: When the immunization was first captured in the subject's record
element.definition: The date the occurrence of the immunization was first captured in the record - potentially significantly after the occurrence of the event.

element.name: primarySource
element.description: Indicates context the data was recorded in
element.definition: An indication that the content of the record is based on information from the person who administered the vaccine. This reflects the context under which the data was originally recorded.
element.comment: Reflects the “reliability” of the content.

element.name: reportOrigin
element.description: Indicates the source of a secondarily reported record
element.definition: The source of the data when the report of the immunization event is not based on information from the person who administered the vaccine.
element.comment: Should not be populated if primarySource = True, not required even if primarySource = False.

binding.name: ImmunizationReportOrigin
binding.description: The source of the data for a record which is not from a primary source.

element.name: location
element.definition: The service delivery location where the vaccine administration occurred.

element.name: manufacturer
element.definition: Name of vaccine manufacturer.

element.name: lotNumber
element.definition: Lot number of the vaccine product.

element.name: expirationDate
element.definition: Date vaccine batch expires.

element.name: site
element.definition: Body site where vaccine was administered.

binding.name: ImmunizationSite
binding.description: The site at which the vaccine was administered.

element.name: route
element.definition: The path by which the vaccine product is taken into the body.

binding.name: ImmunizationRoute
binding.description: The route by which the vaccine was administered.

element.name: doseQuantity
element.definition: The quantity of vaccine product that was administered.

element.name: performer
element.definition: Indicates who performed the immunization event.

element.name: note
element.definition: Extra information about the immunization that is not conveyed by the other attributes.

element.name: reasonCode
element.definition: Reasons why the vaccine was administered.

binding.name: ImmunizationReason
binding.description: The reason why a vaccine was administered.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Condition, Observation or DiagnosticReport that supports why the immunization was administered.

element.name: isSubpotent
element.definition: Indication if a dose is considered to be subpotent. By default, a dose should be considered to be potent.
element.comment: Typically, the recognition of the dose being sub-potent is retrospective, after the administration (ex. notification of a manufacturer recall after administration). However, in the case of a partial administration (the patient moves unexpectedly and only some of the dose is actually administered), subpotency may be recognized immediately, but it is still important to record the event.

element.name: subpotentReason
element.definition: Reason why a dose is considered to be subpotent.

binding.name: SubpotentReason
binding.description: The reason why a dose is considered to be subpotent.

element.name: education
element.definition: Educational material presented to the patient (or guardian) at the time of vaccine administration.

constraint.name: imm-1
constraint.message: One of documentType or reference SHALL be present

element.name: programEligibility
element.description: Patient eligibility for a vaccination program
element.definition: Indicates a patient's eligibility for a funding program.

binding.name: ProgramEligibility
binding.description: The patient's eligibility for a vaccation program.

element.name: fundingSource
element.definition: Indicates the source of the vaccine actually administered. This may be different than the patient eligibility (e.g. the patient may be eligible for a publically purchased vaccine but due to inventory issues, vaccine purchased with private funds was actually administered).

binding.name: FundingSource
binding.description: The source of funding used to purchase the vaccine administered.

element.name: reaction
element.description: Details of a reaction that follows immunization
element.definition: Categorical data indicating that an adverse event is associated in time to an immunization.
element.comment: A reaction may be an indication of an allergy or intolerance and, if this is determined to be the case, it should be recorded as a new AllergyIntolerance resource instance as most systems will not query against past Immunization.reaction elements.

element.name: protocolApplied
element.definition: The protocol (set of recommendations) being followed by the provider who administered the dose.

element.name: documentType
element.definition: Identifier of the material presented to the patient.

element.name: reference
element.definition: Reference pointer to the educational material given to the patient if the information was on line.

element.name: publicationDate
element.definition: Date the educational material was published.

element.name: presentationDate
element.definition: Date the educational material was given to the patient.

element.name: function
element.description: What type of performance was done
element.definition: Describes the type of performance (e.g. ordering provider, administering provider, etc.).

binding.name: ImmunizationFunction
binding.description: The role a practitioner or organization plays in the immunization event.

element.name: actor
element.description: Individual or organization who was performing
element.definition: The practitioner or organization who performed the action.
element.comment: When the individual practitioner who performed the action is known, it is best to send.

element.name: series
element.definition: One possible path to achieve presumed immunity against a disease - within the context of an authority.

element.name: authority
element.description: Who is responsible for publishing the recommendations
element.definition: Indicates the authority who published the protocol (e.g. ACIP) that is being followed.

element.name: targetDisease
element.definition: The vaccine preventable disease the dose is being administered against.

binding.name: TargetDisease
binding.description: The vaccine preventable disease the dose is being administered for.

element.name: doseNumber
element.definition: Nominal position in a series.
element.comment: The use of an integer is preferred if known. A string should only be used in cases where an integer is not available (such as when documenting a recurring booster dose).

element.name: seriesDoses
element.description: Recommended number of doses for immunity
element.definition: The recommended number of doses to achieve immunity.
element.comment: The use of an integer is preferred if known. A string should only be used in cases where an integer is not available (such as when documenting a recurring booster dose).

element.name: date
element.definition: Date of reaction to the immunization.

element.name: detail
element.definition: Details of the reaction.

element.name: reported
element.definition: Self-reported indicator.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: A unique identifier assigned to this immunization evaluation record.

element.name: status
element.definition: Indicates the current status of the evaluation of the vaccination administration event.

binding.name: ImmunizationEvaluationStatus
binding.description: The status of the evaluation being done.

element.name: patient
element.definition: The individual for whom the evaluation is being done.

element.name: date
element.definition: The date the evaluation of the vaccine administration event was performed.

element.name: authority
element.description: Who is responsible for publishing the recommendations
element.definition: Indicates the authority who published the protocol (e.g. ACIP).

element.name: targetDisease
element.definition: The vaccine preventable disease the dose is being evaluated against.

binding.name: EvaluationTargetDisease
binding.description: The vaccine preventable disease the dose is being evaluated against.

element.name: immunizationEvent
element.definition: The vaccine administration event being evaluated.

element.name: doseStatus
element.description: Status of the dose relative to published recommendations
element.definition: Indicates if the dose is valid or not valid with respect to the published recommendations.

binding.name: EvaluationDoseStatus
binding.description: The status of the administered dose relative to the published recommendations for the target disease.

element.name: doseStatusReason
element.definition: Provides an explanation as to why the vaccine administration event is valid or not relative to the published recommendations.

binding.name: EvaluationDoseStatusReason
binding.description: The reason the dose status was assigned.

element.name: description
element.definition: Additional information about the evaluation.

element.name: series
element.definition: One possible path to achieve presumed immunity against a disease - within the context of an authority.

element.name: doseNumber
element.definition: Nominal position in a series.
element.comment: The use of an integer is preferred if known. A string should only be used in cases where an integer is not available (such as when documenting a recurring booster dose).

element.name: seriesDoses
element.description: Recommended number of doses for immunity
element.definition: The recommended number of doses to achieve immunity.
element.comment: The use of an integer is preferred if known. A string should only be used in cases where an integer is not available (such as when documenting a recurring booster dose).

element.name: identifier
element.definition: A unique identifier assigned to this immunization record.

binding.description: Constrained list of immunizaiotn status

element.name: statusReason
element.definition: Indicates the reason the immunization event was not performed.

binding.description: The reason the service was not requested
