element.definition: Indicates another resource that provides a justification for why this service is being requested. May relate to the resources referred to in `supportingInfo`.
element.comment: This element represents why the referral is being made and may be used to decide how the service will be performed, or even if it will be performed at all. To be as specific as possible, a reference to *Observation* or *Condition* should be used if available. Otherwise when referencing *DiagnosticReport* it should contain a finding in `DiagnosticReport.conclusion` and/or `DiagnosticReport.conclusionCode`. When using a reference to *DocumentReference*, the target document should contain clear findings language providing the relevant reason for this service request. Use the CodeableConcept text element in `ServiceRequest.reasonCode` if the data is free (uncoded) text as shown in the [CT Scan example](servicerequest-example-di.html).

element.name: insurance
element.definition: Insurance plans, coverage extensions, pre-authorizations and/or pre-determinations that may be needed for delivering the requested service.

element.name: supportingInfo
element.definition: Additional clinical information about the patient or specimen that may influence the services or their interpretations. This information includes diagnosis, clinical findings and other observations. In laboratory ordering these are typically referred to as "ask at order entry questions (AOEs)". This includes observations explicitly requested by the producer (filler) to provide context or supporting information needed to complete the order. For example, reporting the amount of inspired oxygen for blood gas measurements.
element.comment: To represent information about how the services are to be delivered use the `instructions` element.

element.name: specimen
element.definition: One or more specimens that the laboratory procedure will use.
element.comment: Many diagnostic procedures need a specimen, but the request itself is not actually about the specimen. This element is for when the diagnostic is requested on already existing specimens and the request points to the specimen it applies to. Conversely, if the request is entered first with an unknown specimen, then the [Specimen](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/specimen.html) resource points to the ServiceRequest.

element.name: bodySite
element.definition: Anatomic location where the procedure should be performed. This is the target site.
element.comment: Only used if not implicit in the code found in ServiceRequest.code. If the use case requires BodySite to be handled as a separate resource instead of an inline coded element (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [procedure-targetBodyStructure](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-procedure-targetbodystructure.html).

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.name: note
element.definition: Any other notes and comments made about the service request. For example, internal billing notes.

element.name: patientInstruction
element.definition: Instructions in terms that are understood by the patient or consumer.

element.name: relevantHistory
element.definition: Key events in the history of the request.
element.comment: This might not include provenances for all versions of the request – only those deemed “relevant” or important. This SHALL NOT include the Provenance associated with this current version of the resource. (If that provenance is deemed to be a “relevant” change, it will need to be added as part of a later update. Until then, it can be queried directly as the Provenance that points to this version using _revinclude All Provenances should have some historical version of this Request as their subject.

element.name: type
element.description: Indication of the reason the entity signed the object(s)
element.definition: An indication of the reason that the entity signed this document. This may be explicitly included as part of the signature information and can be used when determining accountability for various actions concerning the document.
element.comment: Examples include attesting to: authorship, correct transcription, and witness of specific event. Also known as a "Commitment Type Indication".

binding.name: SignatureType
binding.description: An indication of the reason that an entity signed the object.

element.name: when
element.definition: When the digital signature was signed.
element.comment: This should agree with the information in the signature.

element.name: who
element.definition: A reference to an application-usable description of the identity that signed (e.g. the signature used their private key).
element.comment: This should agree with the information in the signature.

element.name: onBehalfOf
element.definition: A reference to an application-usable description of the identity that is represented by the signature.
element.comment: The party that can't sign. For example a child.

element.name: targetFormat
element.description: The technical format of the signed resources
element.definition: A mime type that indicates the technical format of the target resources signed by the signature.
element.comment: "xml", "json" and "ttl" are allowed, which describe the simple encodings described in the specification (and imply appropriate bundle support). Otherwise, mime types are legal here.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.name: sigFormat
element.description: The technical format of the signature
element.definition: A mime type that indicates the technical format of the signature. Important mime types are application/signature+xml for X ML DigSig, application/jose for JWS, and image/* for a graphical image of a signature, etc.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.name: data
element.description: The actual signature content (XML DigSig. JWS, picture, etc.)
element.definition: The base64 encoding of the Signature content. When signature is not recorded electronically this element would be empty.
element.comment: Where the signature type is an XML DigSig, the signed content is a FHIR Resource(s), the signature is of the XML form of the Resource(s) using XML-Signature (XMLDIG) "Detached Signature" form.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Id for specimen.

element.name: accessionIdentifier
element.definition: The identifier assigned by the lab when accessioning specimen(s). This is not necessarily the same as the specimen identifier, depending on local lab procedures.

element.name: status
element.definition: The availability of the specimen.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.name: SpecimenStatus
binding.description: Codes providing the status/availability of a specimen.

element.name: type
element.description: Kind of material that forms the specimen
element.definition: The kind of material that forms the specimen.
element.comment: The type can change the way that a specimen is handled and drives what kind of analyses can properly be performed on the specimen. It is frequently used in diagnostic work flow decision making systems.

binding.name: SpecimenType
binding.description: The type of the specimen.

element.name: subject
element.description: Where the specimen came from. This may be from patient(s), from a location (e.g., the source of an environmental sample), or a sampling of a substance or a device
element.definition: Where the specimen came from. This may be from patient(s), from a location (e.g., the source of an environmental sample), or a sampling of a substance or a device.

element.name: receivedTime
element.description: The time when specimen was received for processing
element.definition: Time when specimen was received for processing or testing.

element.name: parent
element.description: Specimen from which this specimen originated
element.definition: Reference to the parent (source) specimen which is used when the specimen was either derived from or a component of another specimen.
element.comment: The parent specimen could be the source from which the current specimen is derived by some processing step (e.g. an aliquot or isolate or extracted nucleic acids from clinical samples) or one of many specimens that were combined to create a pooled sample.

element.name: request
element.definition: Details concerning a service request that required a specimen to be collected.
element.comment: The request may be explicit or implied such with a ServiceRequest that requires a blood draw.

element.name: collection
element.definition: Details concerning the specimen collection.

element.name: processing
element.definition: Details concerning processing and processing steps for the specimen.

element.name: container
element.definition: The container holding the specimen. The recursive nature of containers; i.e. blood in tube in tray in rack is not addressed here.

element.name: condition
element.definition: A mode or state of being that describes the nature of the specimen.
element.comment: Specimen condition is an observation made about the specimen. It's a point-in-time assessment. It can be used to assess its quality or appropriateness for a specific test.

binding.name: SpecimenCondition
binding.description: Codes describing the state of the specimen.

element.name: note
element.definition: To communicate any details or issues about the specimen or during the specimen collection. (for example: broken vial, sent with patient, frozen).

element.name: collector
element.definition: Person who collected the specimen.

element.name: collected
element.definition: Time when specimen was collected from subject - the physiologically relevant time.

element.name: duration
element.description: How long it took to collect specimen
element.definition: The span of time over which the collection of a specimen occurred.

element.name: quantity
element.definition: The quantity of specimen collected; for instance the volume of a blood sample, or the physical measurement of an anatomic pathology sample.

element.name: method
element.definition: A coded value specifying the technique that is used to perform the procedure.

binding.name: SpecimenCollectionMethod
binding.description: The technique that is used to perform the procedure.

element.name: bodySite
element.definition: Anatomical location from which the specimen was collected (if subject is a patient). This is the target site. This element is not used for environmental specimens.
element.comment: If the use case requires BodySite to be handled as a separate resource instead of an inline coded element (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [bodySite](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-bodysite.html).

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.name: fastingStatus
element.description: Whether or how long patient abstained from food and/or drink
element.definition: Abstinence or reduction from some or all food, drink, or both, for a period of time prior to sample collection.
element.comment: Representing fasting status using this element is preferred to representing it with an observation using a 'pre-coordinated code' such as LOINC 2005-7 (Calcium [Moles/​time] in 2 hour Urine --12 hours fasting), or using a component observation ` such as `Observation.component code` = LOINC 49541-6 (Fasting status - Reported).

binding.name: FastingStatus
binding.description: Codes describing the fasting status of the patient.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Id for container. There may be multiple; a manufacturer's bar code, lab assigned identifier, etc. The container ID may differ from the specimen id in some circumstances.

element.name: description
element.definition: Textual description of the container.

element.name: type
element.description: Kind of container directly associated with specimen
element.definition: The type of container associated with the specimen (e.g. slide, aliquot, etc.).

binding.name: SpecimenContainerType
binding.description: Type of specimen container.

element.name: capacity
element.definition: The capacity (volume or other measure) the container may contain.

element.name: specimenQuantity
element.definition: The quantity of specimen in the container; may be volume, dimensions, or other appropriate measurements, depending on the specimen type.

element.name: additive
element.definition: Introduced substance to preserve, maintain or enhance the specimen. Examples: Formalin, Citrate, EDTA.

binding.name: SpecimenContainerAdditive
binding.description: Substance added to specimen container.

element.name: container-sequenceNumber
element.description: The sequence number of the sample
element.definition: An assigned number on the specimen denoting the order of collection.

element.name: description
element.definition: Textual description of procedure.

element.name: procedure
element.description: Indicates the treatment step applied to the specimen
element.definition: A coded value specifying the procedure used to process the specimen.

binding.name: SpecimenProcessingProcedure
binding.description: Type indicating the technique used to process the specimen.

element.name: additive
element.description: Material used in the processing step
element.definition: Material used in the processing step.

element.name: time
element.description: Date and time of specimen processing
element.definition: A record of the time or period when the specimen processing occurred. For example the time of sample fixation or the period of time the sample was in formalin.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Unique identifier for the substance.
element.comment: This identifier is associated with the kind of substance in contrast to the Substance.instance.identifier which is associated with the package/container.

element.name: status
element.definition: A code to indicate if the substance is actively used.

binding.name: FHIRSubstanceStatus
binding.description: A code to indicate if the substance is actively used.

element.name: category
element.description: What class/type of substance this is
element.definition: A code that classifies the general type of substance. This is used for searching, sorting and display purposes.
element.comment: The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set. More fine-grained filtering can be performed using the metadata and/or terminology hierarchy in Substance.code.

binding.name: SubstanceCategory
binding.description: Category or classification of substance.

element.name: code
element.definition: A code (or set of codes) that identify this substance.
element.comment: This could be a reference to an externally defined code. It could also be a locally assigned code (e.g. a formulary), optionally with translations to the standard drug codes.

binding.name: SubstanceCode
binding.description: Substance codes.

element.name: description
element.description: Textual description of the substance, comments
element.definition: A description of the substance - its appearance, handling requirements, and other usage notes.

element.name: instance
element.description: If this describes a specific package/container of the substance
element.definition: Substance may be used to describe a kind of substance, or a specific package/container of the substance: an instance.

element.name: ingredient
element.definition: A substance can be composed of other substances.

element.name: quantity
element.definition: The amount of the ingredient in the substance - a concentration ratio.

element.name: substance
element.definition: Another substance that is a component of this substance.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Identifier associated with the package/container (usually a label affixed directly).

element.name: expiry
element.description: When no longer valid to use
element.definition: When the substance is no longer valid to use. For some substances, a single arbitrary date is used for expiry.

element.name: quantity
element.description: Amount of substance in the package
element.definition: The amount of the substance.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: The business identifier for this task.

element.name: instantiatesCanonical
element.definition: The URL pointing to a *FHIR*-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Task.

element.name: instantiatesUri
element.definition: The URL pointing to an *externally* maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Task.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: BasedOn refers to a higher-level authorization that triggered the creation of the task. It references a "request" resource such as a ServiceRequest, MedicationRequest, ServiceRequest, CarePlan, etc. which is distinct from the "request" resource the task is seeking to fulfill. This latter resource is referenced by FocusOn. For example, based on a ServiceRequest (= BasedOn), a task is created to fulfill a procedureRequest ( = FocusOn ) to collect a specimen from a patient.

element.name: groupIdentifier
element.definition: An identifier that links together multiple tasks and other requests that were created in the same context.

element.name: partOf
element.definition: Task that this particular task is part of.
element.comment: This should usually be 0..1.

element.name: status
element.definition: The current status of the task.

binding.name: TaskStatus
binding.description: The current status of the task.

element.name: statusReason
element.definition: An explanation as to why this task is held, failed, was refused, etc.
element.comment: This applies to the current status. Look at the history of the task to see reasons for past statuses.

binding.name: TaskStatusReason
binding.description: Codes to identify the reason for current status. These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.

element.name: businessStatus
element.definition: Contains business-specific nuances of the business state.

binding.name: TaskBusinessStatus
binding.description: The domain-specific business-contextual sub-state of the task. For example: "Blood drawn", "IV inserted", "Awaiting physician signature", etc.

element.name: intent
element.description: unknown | proposal | plan | order | original-order | reflex-order | filler-order | instance-order | option
element.definition: Indicates the "level" of actionability associated with the Task, i.e. i+R[9]Cs this a proposed task, a planned task, an actionable task, etc.
element.comment:
This element is immutable. Proposed tasks, planned tasks, etc. must be distinct instances.
In most cases, Tasks will have an intent of "order".

binding.name: TaskIntent
binding.description: Distinguishes whether the task is a proposal, plan or full order.

element.name: priority
element.definition: Indicates how quickly the Task should be addressed with respect to other requests.

binding.name: TaskPriority
binding.description: The task's priority.

element.name: code
element.definition: A name or code (or both) briefly describing what the task involves.
element.comment: The title (eg "My Tasks", "Outstanding Tasks for Patient X") should go into the code.

binding.name: TaskCode
binding.description: Codes to identify what the task involves. These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.

element.name: description
element.definition: A free-text description of what is to be performed.

element.name: focus
element.definition: The request being actioned or the resource being manipulated by this task.
element.comment: If multiple resources need to be manipulated, use sub-tasks. (This ensures that status can be tracked independently for each referenced resource.).

element.name: for
element.definition: The entity who benefits from the performance of the service specified in the task (e.g., the patient).

element.name: encounter
element.description: Healthcare event during which this task originated
element.definition: The healthcare event (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this task was created.

element.name: executionPeriod
element.description: Start and end time of execution
element.definition: Identifies the time action was first taken against the task (start) and/or the time final action was taken against the task prior to marking it as completed (end).

element.name: authoredOn
element.definition: The date and time this task was created.

element.name: lastModified
element.definition: The date and time of last modification to this task.

element.name: requester
element.description: Who is asking for task to be done
element.definition: The creator of the task.

element.name: performerType
element.definition: The kind of participant that should perform the task.

binding.name: TaskPerformerType
binding.description: The type(s) of task performers allowed.

element.name: owner
element.definition: Individual organization or Device currently responsible for task execution.
element.comment: Tasks may be created with an owner not yet identified.

element.name: location
element.definition: Principal physical location where the this task is performed.

element.name: reasonCode
element.definition: A description or code indicating why this task needs to be performed.
element.comment: This should only be included if there is no focus or if it differs from the reason indicated on the focus.

binding.name: TaskReason
binding.description: Indicates why the task is needed. E.g. Suspended because patient admitted to hospital.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: A resource reference indicating why this task needs to be performed.
element.comment: Tasks might be justified based on an Observation, a Condition, a past or planned procedure, etc. This should only be included if there is no focus or if it differs from the reason indicated on the focus. Use the CodeableConcept text element in `Task.reasonCode` if the data is free (uncoded) text.

element.name: insurance
element.definition: Insurance plans, coverage extensions, pre-authorizations and/or pre-determinations that may be relevant to the Task.

element.name: note
element.definition: Free-text information captured about the task as it progresses.

element.name: relevantHistory
element.description: Key events in history of the Task
element.definition: Links to Provenance records for past versions of this Task that identify key state transitions or updates that are likely to be relevant to a user looking at the current version of the task.
element.comment: This element does not point to the Provenance associated with the *current* version of the resource - as it would be created after this version existed. The Provenance for the current version can be retrieved with a _revinclude.

element.name: restriction
element.definition: If the Task.focus is a request resource and the task is seeking fulfillment (i.e. is asking for the request to be actioned), this element identifies any limitations on what parts of the referenced request should be actioned.

element.name: input
element.definition: Additional information that may be needed in the execution of the task.

element.name: output
element.description: Information produced as part of task
element.definition: Outputs produced by the Task.

element.name: type
element.definition: A code or description indicating how the input is intended to be used as part of the task execution.
element.comment: If referencing a BPMN workflow or Protocol, the "system" is the URL for the workflow definition and the code is the "name" of the required input.

binding.name: TaskInputParameterType
binding.description: Codes to identify types of input parameters. These will typically be specific to a particular workflow. E.g. "Comparison source", "Applicable consent", "Concomitent Medications", etc.

element.name: value
element.description: Content to use in performing the task
element.definition: The value of the input parameter as a basic type.

element.name: type
element.definition: The name of the Output parameter.

binding.name: TaskOutputParameterType
binding.description: Codes to identify types of input parameters. These will typically be specific to a particular workflow. E.g. "Identified issues", "Preliminary results", "Filler order", "Final results", etc.

element.name: value
element.definition: The value of the Output parameter as a basic type.

element.name: repetitions
element.definition: Indicates the number of times the requested action should occur.

element.name: period
element.definition: Over what time-period is fulfillment sought.
element.comment: Note that period.high is the due date representing the time by which the task should be completed.

element.name: recipient
element.definition: For requests that are targeted to more than on potential recipient/target, for whom is fulfillment sought?

element.name: identifier
element.definition: The business identifier for this task.

element.name: instantiatesCanonical
element.definition: The URL pointing to a *FHIR*-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Task.

element.name: instantiatesUri
element.definition: The URL pointing to an *externally* maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Task.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: BasedOn refers to a higher-level authorization that triggered the creation of the task. It references a "request" resource such as a ServiceRequest, MedicationRequest, ServiceRequest, CarePlan, etc. which is distinct from the "request" resource the task is seeking to fulfill. This latter resource is referenced by FocusOn. For example, based on a ServiceRequest (= BasedOn), a task is created to fulfill a procedureRequest ( = FocusOn ) to collect a specimen from a patient.

element.name: groupIdentifier
element.definition: An identifier that links together multiple tasks and other requests that were created in the same context.

element.name: partOf
element.definition: Task that this particular task is part of.
element.comment: This should usually be 0..1.

element.name: status
element.description: The potential performer who claimed ownership of the task has decided not to execute it prior to performing any action
element.definition: The current status of the task.

binding.name: TaskStatus
binding.description: The current status of the task.

element.name: statusReason
element.definition: An explanation as to why this task is held, failed, was refused, etc.
element.comment: This applies to the current status. Look at the history of the task to see reasons for past statuses.

element.name: businessStatus
element.definition: Contains business-specific nuances of the business state.

binding.name: TaskBusinessStatus
binding.description: The domain-specific business-contextual sub-state of the task. For example: "Blood drawn", "IV inserted", "Awaiting physician signature", etc.

element.name: intent
element.description: unknown | proposal | plan | order | original-order | reflex-order | filler-order | instance-order | option
element.definition: Indicates the "level" of actionability associated with the Task, i.e. i+R[9]Cs this a proposed task, a planned task, an actionable task, etc.
element.comment:
This element is immutable. Proposed tasks, planned tasks, etc. must be distinct instances.
In most cases, Tasks will have an intent of "order".

binding.name: TaskIntent
binding.description: Distinguishes whether the task is a proposal, plan or full order.

element.name: priority
element.definition: Indicates how quickly the Task should be addressed with respect to other requests.

binding.name: TaskPriority
binding.description: The task's priority.

element.name: code
element.definition: A name or code (or both) briefly describing what the task involves.
element.comment: The title (eg "My Tasks", "Outstanding Tasks for Patient X") should go into the code.

binding.name: TaskCode
binding.description: Codes to identify what the task involves. These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.

element.name: description
element.definition: A free-text description of what is to be performed.

element.name: focus
element.definition: The request being actioned or the resource being manipulated by this task.
element.comment: If multiple resources need to be manipulated, use sub-tasks. (This ensures that status can be tracked independently for each referenced resource.).

element.name: for
element.definition: The entity who benefits from the performance of the service specified in the task (e.g., the patient).

element.name: encounter
element.description: Healthcare event during which this task originated
element.definition: The healthcare event (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this task was created.

element.name: executionPeriod
element.description: The timing the task was rejected and the reason.
element.definition: Identifies the time action was first taken against the task (start) and/or the time final action was taken against the task prior to marking it as completed (end).

element.name: authoredOn
element.definition: The date and time this task was created.

element.name: lastModified
element.definition: The date and time of last modification to this task.

element.name: requester
element.description: Who is asking for task to be done
element.definition: The creator of the task.

element.name: performerType
element.definition: The kind of participant that should perform the task.

binding.name: TaskPerformerType
binding.description: The type(s) of task performers allowed.

element.name: owner
element.definition: Individual organization or Device currently responsible for task execution.
element.comment: Tasks may be created with an owner not yet identified.

element.name: location
element.definition: Principal physical location where the this task is performed.

element.name: reasonCode
element.definition: A description or code indicating why this task needs to be performed.
element.comment: This should only be included if there is no focus or if it differs from the reason indicated on the focus.

binding.name: TaskReason
binding.description: Indicates why the task is needed. E.g. Suspended because patient admitted to hospital.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: A resource reference indicating why this task needs to be performed.
element.comment: Tasks might be justified based on an Observation, a Condition, a past or planned procedure, etc. This should only be included if there is no focus or if it differs from the reason indicated on the focus. Use the CodeableConcept text element in `Task.reasonCode` if the data is free (uncoded) text.

element.name: insurance
element.definition: Insurance plans, coverage extensions, pre-authorizations and/or pre-determinations that may be relevant to the Task.

element.name: note
element.definition: Free-text information captured about the task as it progresses.

element.name: relevantHistory
element.description: Key events in history of the Task
element.definition: Links to Provenance records for past versions of this Task that identify key state transitions or updates that are likely to be relevant to a user looking at the current version of the task.
element.comment: This element does not point to the Provenance associated with the *current* version of the resource - as it would be created after this version existed. The Provenance for the current version can be retrieved with a _revinclude.

element.name: restriction
element.definition: If the Task.focus is a request resource and the task is seeking fulfillment (i.e. is asking for the request to be actioned), this element identifies any limitations on what parts of the referenced request should be actioned.

element.name: input
element.definition: Additional information that may be needed in the execution of the task.

element.name: output
element.description: Information produced as part of task
element.definition: Outputs produced by the Task.

element.name: event
element.definition: Identifies specific times when the event occurs.

element.name: repeat
element.description: When the event is to occur
element.definition: A set of rules that describe when the event is scheduled.

constraint.name: tim-1
constraint.message: if there's a duration, there needs to be duration units

constraint.name: tim-2
constraint.message: if there's a period, there needs to be period units

constraint.name: tim-4
constraint.message: duration SHALL be a non-negative value

constraint.name: tim-5
constraint.message: period SHALL be a non-negative value

constraint.name: tim-6
constraint.message: If there's a periodMax, there must be a period

constraint.name: tim-7
constraint.message: If there's a durationMax, there must be a duration

constraint.name: tim-8
constraint.message: If there's a countMax, there must be a count

constraint.name: tim-9
constraint.message: If there's an offset, there must be a when (and not C, CM, CD, CV)

constraint.name: tim-10
constraint.message: If there's a timeOfDay, there cannot be a when, or vice versa

element.name: code
element.description: BID | TID | QID | AM | PM | QD | QOD | +
element.definition: A code for the timing schedule (or just text in code.text). Some codes such as BID are ubiquitous, but many institutions define their own additional codes. If a code is provided, the code is understood to be a complete statement of whatever is specified in the structured timing data, and either the code or the data may be used to interpret the Timing, with the exception that .repeat.bounds still applies over the code (and is not contained in the code).
element.comment: BID etc. are defined as 'at institutionally specified times'. For example, an institution may choose that BID is "always at 7am and 6pm". If it is inappropriate for this choice to be made, the code BID should not be used. Instead, a distinct organization-specific code should be used in place of the HL7-defined BID code and/or a structured representation should be used (in this case, specifying the two event times).

binding.name: TimingAbbreviation
binding.description: Code for a known / defined timing pattern.

element.name: bounds
element.description: Length/Range of lengths, or (Start and/or end) limits
element.definition: Either a duration for the length of the timing schedule, a range of possible length, or outer bounds for start and/or end limits of the timing schedule.

element.name: count
element.definition: A total count of the desired number of repetitions across the duration of the entire timing specification. If countMax is present, this element indicates the lower bound of the allowed range of count values.
element.comment: If you have both bounds and count, then this should be understood as within the bounds period, until count times happens.

element.name: countMax
element.description: Maximum number of times to repeat
element.definition: If present, indicates that the count is a range - so to perform the action between [count] and [countMax] times.

element.name: duration
element.definition: How long this thing happens for when it happens. If durationMax is present, this element indicates the lower bound of the allowed range of the duration.
element.comment: For some events the duration is part of the definition of the event (e.g. IV infusions, where the duration is implicit in the specified quantity and rate). For others, it's part of the timing specification (e.g. exercise).

element.name: durationMax
element.definition: If present, indicates that the duration is a range - so to perform the action between [duration] and [durationMax] time length.
element.comment: For some events the duration is part of the definition of the event (e.g. IV infusions, where the duration is implicit in the specified quantity and rate). For others, it's part of the timing specification (e.g. exercise).

element.name: durationUnit
element.description: s | min | h | d | wk | mo | a - unit of time (UCUM)
element.definition: The units of time for the duration, in UCUM units.

binding.name: UnitsOfTime
binding.description: A unit of time (units from UCUM).

element.name: frequency
element.description: Event occurs frequency times per period
element.definition: The number of times to repeat the action within the specified period. If frequencyMax is present, this element indicates the lower bound of the allowed range of the frequency.

element.name: frequencyMax
element.description: Event occurs up to frequencyMax times per period
element.definition: If present, indicates that the frequency is a range - so to repeat between [frequency] and [frequencyMax] times within the period or period range.

element.name: period
element.description: Event occurs frequency times per period
element.definition: Indicates the duration of time over which repetitions are to occur; e.g. to express "3 times per day", 3 would be the frequency and "1 day" would be the period. If periodMax is present, this element indicates the lower bound of the allowed range of the period length.

element.name: periodMax
element.definition: If present, indicates that the period is a range from [period] to [periodMax], allowing expressing concepts such as "do this once every 3-5 days.

element.name: periodUnit
element.description: s | min | h | d | wk | mo | a - unit of time (UCUM)
element.definition: The units of time for the period in UCUM units.

binding.name: UnitsOfTime
binding.description: A unit of time (units from UCUM).

element.name: dayOfWeek
element.description: mon | tue | wed | thu | fri | sat | sun
element.definition: If one or more days of week is provided, then the action happens only on the specified day(s).
element.comment: If no days are specified, the action is assumed to happen every day as otherwise specified. The elements frequency and period cannot be used as well as dayOfWeek.

element.name: timeOfDay
element.definition: Specified time of day for action to take place.
element.comment: When time of day is specified, it is inferred that the action happens every day (as filtered by dayofWeek) on the specified times. The elements when, frequency and period cannot be used as well as timeOfDay.

element.name: when
element.description: Code for time period of occurrence
element.definition: An approximate time period during the day, potentially linked to an event of daily living that indicates when the action should occur.
element.comment: When more than one event is listed, the event is tied to the union of the specified events.

binding.name: EventTiming
binding.description: Real world event relating to the schedule.

element.name: offset
element.definition: The number of minutes from the event. If the event code does not indicate whether the minutes is before or after the event, then the offset is assumed to be after the event.

element.name: type
element.description: named-event | periodic | data-changed | data-added | data-modified | data-removed | data-accessed | data-access-ended
element.definition: The type of triggering event.

binding.name: TriggerType
binding.description: The type of trigger.

element.name: name
element.description: Name or URI that identifies the event
element.definition: A formal name for the event. This may be an absolute URI that identifies the event formally (e.g. from a trigger registry), or a simple relative URI that identifies the event in a local context.
element.comment: An event name can be provided for all event types, but is required for named events. If a name is provided for a type other than named events, it is considered to be a shorthand for the semantics described by the formal description of the event.

element.name: timing
element.definition: The timing of the event (if this is a periodic trigger).

element.name: data
element.definition: The triggering data of the event (if this is a data trigger). If more than one data is requirement is specified, then all the data requirements must be true.
element.comment: This element shall be present for any data type trigger.

element.name: condition
element.definition: A boolean-valued expression that is evaluated in the context of the container of the trigger definition and returns whether or not the trigger fires.
element.comment: This element can be only be specified for data type triggers and provides additional semantics for the trigger. The context available within the condition is based on the type of data event. For all events, the current resource will be available as context. In addition, for modification events, the previous resource will also be available. The expression may be inlined, or may be a simple absolute URI, which is a reference to a named expression within a logic library referenced by a library element or extension within the containing resource. If the expression is a FHIR Path expression, it evaluates in the context of a resource of one of the type identified in the data requirement, and may also refer to the variable %previous for delta comparisons on events of type data-changed, data-modified, and data-deleted which will always have the same type.

element.name: ombCategory
element.description: Hispanic or Latino|Not Hispanic or Latino
element.definition: The 2 ethnicity category codes according to the [OMB Standards for Maintaining, Collecting, and Presenting Federal Data on Race and Ethnicity, Statistical Policy Directive No. 15, as revised, October 30, 1997](https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-1997-10-30/pdf/97-28653.pdf).

element.name: detailed
element.definition: The 41 CDC ethnicity codes that are grouped under one of the 2 OMB ethnicity category codes.

element.name: text
element.definition: Plain text representation of the ethnicity concept(s).

element.name: url
element.description: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comment: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition SHALL be a URI for the Structure Definition defining the extension.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Unique instance identifiers assigned to a device by manufacturers other organizations or owners.
element.comment: The barcode string from a barcode present on a device label or package may identify the instance, include names given to the device in local usage, or may identify the type of device. If the identifier identifies the type of device, Device.type element should be used.

element.name: definition
element.description: The reference to the definition for the device
element.definition: The reference to the definition for the device.

element.name: udiCarrier
element.definition: Unique device identifier (UDI) assigned to device label or package. Note that the Device may include multiple udiCarriers as it either may include just the udiCarrier for the jurisdiction it is sold, or for multiple jurisdictions it could have been sold.
element.comment: Some devices may not have UDI information (for example. historical data or patient reported data).

element.name: status
element.definition: Status of the Device availability.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes inactive and entered-in-error that mark the device (record)as not currently valid.

binding.name: FHIRDeviceStatus
binding.description: The availability status of the device.

element.name: statusReason
element.description: online | paused | standby | offline | not-ready | transduc-discon | hw-discon | off
element.definition: Reason for the dtatus of the Device availability.

binding.name: FHIRDeviceStatusReason
binding.description: The availability status reason of the device.

element.name: distinctIdentifier
element.definition: The distinct identification string as required by regulation for a human cell, tissue, or cellular and tissue-based product.
element.comment: For example, this applies to devices in the United States regulated under *Code of Federal Regulation 21CFR§1271.290(c)*.

element.name: manufacturer
element.definition: A name of the manufacturer.

element.name: manufactureDate
element.description: Date when the device was made
element.definition: The date and time when the device was manufactured.

element.name: expirationDate
element.description: Date and time of expiry of this device (if applicable)
element.definition: The date and time beyond which this device is no longer valid or should not be used (if applicable).

element.name: lotNumber
element.definition: Lot number assigned by the manufacturer.

element.name: serialNumber
element.description: Serial number assigned by the manufacturer
element.definition: The serial number assigned by the organization when the device was manufactured.
element.comment: Alphanumeric Maximum 20.

element.name: deviceName
element.description: The name of the device as given by the manufacturer
element.definition: This represents the manufacturer's name of the device as provided by the device, from a UDI label, or by a person describing the Device. This typically would be used when a person provides the name(s) or when the device represents one of the names available from DeviceDefinition.

element.name: modelNumber
element.description: The model number for the device
element.definition: The model number for the device.

element.name: partNumber
element.description: The part number of the device
element.definition: The part number of the device.
element.comment: Alphanumeric Maximum 20.

element.name: type
element.description: The kind or type of device
element.definition: The kind or type of device.

binding.description: Codes to identify medical devices

element.name: specialization
element.description: The capabilities supported on a device, the standards to which the device conforms for a particular purpose, and used for the communication
element.definition: The capabilities supported on a device, the standards to which the device conforms for a particular purpose, and used for the communication.

element.name: version
element.description: The actual design of the device or software version running on the device
element.definition: The actual design of the device or software version running on the device.

element.name: property
element.description: The actual configuration settings of a device as it actually operates, e.g., regulation status, time properties
element.definition: The actual configuration settings of a device as it actually operates, e.g., regulation status, time properties.

element.name: patient
element.description: Patient to whom Device is affixed
element.definition: Patient information, If the device is affixed to a person.

element.name: owner
element.definition: An organization that is responsible for the provision and ongoing maintenance of the device.

element.name: contact
element.definition: Contact details for an organization or a particular human that is responsible for the device.
element.comment: used for troubleshooting etc.

element.name: location
element.definition: The place where the device can be found.

element.name: url
element.definition: A network address on which the device may be contacted directly.
element.comment: If the device is running a FHIR server, the network address should be the Base URL from which a conformance statement may be retrieved.

element.name: note
element.definition: Descriptive information, usage information or implantation information that is not captured in an existing element.

element.name: safety
element.definition: Provides additional safety characteristics about a medical device. For example devices containing latex.

element.name: parent
element.definition: The parent device.

typeInfo.name: USCoreLaboratoryResultObservationProfile
typeInfo.label: US Core Laboratory Result Observation Profile

element.name: identifier
element.definition: A unique identifier assigned to this observation.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: A plan, proposal or order that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this event. For example, a MedicationRequest may require a patient to have laboratory test performed before it is dispensed.

element.name: partOf
element.definition: A larger event of which this particular Observation is a component or step. For example, an observation as part of a procedure.
element.comment: To link an Observation to an Encounter use `encounter`. See the [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#obsgrouping) below for guidance on referencing another Observation.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of the result value.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

element.name: category
element.definition: A code that classifies the general type of observation being made.
element.comment: In addition to the required category valueset, this element allows various categorization schemes based on the owner’s definition of the category and effectively multiple categories can be used at once. The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.

binding.name: ObservationCategory
binding.description: Codes for high level observation categories.

element.name: Laboratory
element.definition: A code that classifies the general type of observation being made.
element.comment: In addition to the required category valueset, this element allows various categorization schemes based on the owner’s definition of the category and effectively multiple categories can be used at once. The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.

binding.name: ObservationCategory
binding.description: Codes for high level observation categories.

element.name: code
element.definition: The test that was performed. A LOINC **SHALL** be used if the concept is present in LOINC.
element.comment: The typical patterns for codes are: 1) a LOINC code either as a translation from a "local" code or as a primary code, or 2) a local code only if no suitable LOINC exists, or 3) both the local and the LOINC translation. Systems SHALL be capable of sending the local code if one exists. When using LOINC , Use either the SHORTNAME or LONG_COMMON_NAME field for the display.

binding.description: LOINC codes

element.name: subject
element.description: Who and/or what the observation is about
element.definition: The patient, or group of patients, location, or device this observation is about and into whose record the observation is placed. If the actual focus of the observation is different from the subject (or a sample of, part, or region of the subject), the `focus` element or the `code` itself specifies the actual focus of the observation.
element.comment: One would expect this element to be a cardinality of 1..1. The only circumstance in which the subject can be missing is when the observation is made by a device that does not know the patient. In this case, the observation SHALL be matched to a patient through some context/channel matching technique, and at this point, the observation should be updated.

element.name: focus
element.description: What the observation is about, when it is not about the subject of record
element.definition: The actual focus of an observation when it is not the patient of record representing something or someone associated with the patient such as a spouse, parent, fetus, or donor. For example, fetus observations in a mother's record. The focus of an observation could also be an existing condition, an intervention, the subject's diet, another observation of the subject, or a body structure such as tumor or implanted device. An example use case would be using the Observation resource to capture whether the mother is trained to change her child's tracheostomy tube. In this example, the child is the patient of record and the mother is the focus.
element.comment: Typically, an observation is made about the subject - a patient, or group of patients, location, or device - and the distinction between the subject and what is directly measured for an observation is specified in the observation code itself ( e.g., "Blood Glucose") and does not need to be represented separately using this element. Use `specimen` if a reference to a specimen is required. If a code is required instead of a resource use either `bodysite` for bodysites or the standard extension [focusCode](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-observation-focuscode.html).

element.name: encounter
element.description: Healthcare event during which this observation is made
element.definition: The healthcare event (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this observation is made.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some events may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter (e.g. pre-admission laboratory tests).

element.name: effective
element.definition: For lab tests this is the specimen collection date. For Ask at Order Entry Questions (AOE)'s this is the date the question was asked.
element.comment: At least a date should be present unless this observation is a historical report. For recording imprecise or "fuzzy" times (For example, a blood glucose measurement taken "after breakfast") use the [Timing](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/datatypes.html#timing) datatype which allow the measurement to be tied to regular life events.

constraint.name: us-core-1
constraint.message: Datetime must be at least to day.

element.name: issued
element.description: Date/Time this version was made available
element.definition: The date and time this version of the observation was made available to providers, typically after the results have been reviewed and verified.
element.comment: For Observations that don’t require review and verification, it may be the same as the [`lastUpdated` ](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource-definitions.html#Meta.lastUpdated) time of the resource itself. For Observations that do require review and verification for certain updates, it might not be the same as the `lastUpdated` time of the resource itself due to a non-clinically significant update that doesn’t require the new version to be reviewed and verified again.

element.name: performer
element.description: Who is responsible for the observation
element.definition: Who was responsible for asserting the observed value as "true".

element.name: value
element.definition: The Laboratory result value. If a coded value, the valueCodeableConcept.code **SHOULD** be selected from [SNOMED CT](http://hl7.org/fhir/ValueSet/uslab-obs-codedresults). If a numeric value, valueQuantity.code **SHALL** be selected from [UCUM](http://unitsofmeasure.org). A FHIR [UCUM Codes value set](http://hl7.org/fhir/STU3/valueset-ucum-units.html) that defines all UCUM codes is in the FHIR specification.
element.comment: An observation may have; 1) a single value here, 2) both a value and a set of related or component values, or 3) only a set of related or component values. If a value is present, the datatype for this element should be determined by Observation.code. A CodeableConcept with just a text would be used instead of a string if the field was usually coded, or if the type associated with the Observation.code defines a coded value. For additional guidance, see the [Notes section](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#notes) below.

constraint.name: us-core-4
constraint.message: SHOULD use Snomed CT for coded Results

constraint.name: us-core-3
constraint.message: SHALL use UCUM for coded quantity units.

element.name: dataAbsentReason
element.definition: Provides a reason why the expected value in the element Observation.value[x] is missing.
element.comment:
Null or exceptional values can be represented two ways in FHIR Observations. One way is to simply include them in the value set and represent the exceptions in the value. For example, measurement values for a serology test could be "detected", "not detected", "inconclusive", or "specimen unsatisfactory".
The alternate way is to use the value element for actual observations and use the explicit dataAbsentReason element to record exceptional values. For example, the dataAbsentReason code "error" could be used when the measurement was not completed. Note that an observation may only be reported if there are values to report. For example differential cell counts values may be reported only when > 0. Because of these options, use-case agreements are required to interpret general observations for null or exceptional values.

element.name: interpretation
element.definition: A categorical assessment of an observation value. For example, high, low, normal.
element.comment: Historically used for laboratory results (known as 'abnormal flag' ), its use extends to other use cases where coded interpretations are relevant. Often reported as one or more simple compact codes this element is often placed adjacent to the result value in reports and flow sheets to signal the meaning/normalcy status of the result.

binding.name: ObservationInterpretation
binding.description: Codes identifying interpretations of observations.

element.name: note
element.definition: Comments about the observation or the results.
element.comment: May include general statements about the observation, or statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable results values, or information about its source when relevant to its interpretation.

element.name: bodySite
element.definition: Indicates the site on the subject's body where the observation was made (i.e. the target site).
element.comment:
Only used if not implicit in code found in Observation.code. In many systems, this may be represented as a related observation instead of an inline component.
If the use case requires BodySite to be handled as a separate resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension[ bodySite](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-bodysite.html).

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.name: method
element.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to perform the observation.
element.comment: Only used if not implicit in code for Observation.code.

binding.name: ObservationMethod
binding.description: Methods for simple observations.

element.name: specimen
element.definition: The specimen that was used when this observation was made.
element.comment: Should only be used if not implicit in code found in `Observation.code`. Observations are not made on specimens themselves; they are made on a subject, but in many cases by the means of a specimen. Note that although specimens are often involved, they are not always tracked and reported explicitly. Also note that observation resources may be used in contexts that track the specimen explicitly (e.g. Diagnostic Report).

element.name: device
element.definition: The device used to generate the observation data.
element.comment: Note that this is not meant to represent a device involved in the transmission of the result, e.g., a gateway. Such devices may be documented using the Provenance resource where relevant.

element.name: referenceRange
element.definition: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range. Multiple reference ranges are interpreted as an "OR". In other words, to represent two distinct target populations, two `referenceRange` elements would be used.
element.comment: Most observations only have one generic reference range. Systems MAY choose to restrict to only supplying the relevant reference range based on knowledge about the patient (e.g., specific to the patient's age, gender, weight and other factors), but this might not be possible or appropriate. Whenever more than one reference range is supplied, the differences between them SHOULD be provided in the reference range and/or age properties.

constraint.name: obs-3
constraint.message: Must have at least a low or a high or text

element.name: hasMember
element.description: Related resource that belongs to the Observation group
element.definition: This observation is a group observation (e.g. a battery, a panel of tests, a set of vital sign measurements) that includes the target as a member of the group.
element.comment: When using this element, an observation will typically have either a value or a set of related resources, although both may be present in some cases. For a discussion on the ways Observations can assembled in groups together, see [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#obsgrouping) below. Note that a system may calculate results from [QuestionnaireResponse](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/questionnaireresponse.html) into a final score and represent the score as an Observation.

element.name: derivedFrom
element.description: Related measurements the observation is made from
element.definition: The target resource that represents a measurement from which this observation value is derived. For example, a calculated anion gap or a fetal measurement based on an ultrasound image.
element.comment: All the reference choices that are listed in this element can represent clinical observations and other measurements that may be the source for a derived value. The most common reference will be another Observation. For a discussion on the ways Observations can assembled in groups together, see [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#obsgrouping) below.

element.name: component
element.definition: Some observations have multiple component observations. These component observations are expressed as separate code value pairs that share the same attributes. Examples include systolic and diastolic component observations for blood pressure measurement and multiple component observations for genetics observations.
element.comment: For a discussion on the ways Observations can be assembled in groups together see [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#notes) below.

typeInfo.name: USCorePediatricBMIforAgeObservationProfile
typeInfo.label: US Core Pediatric BMI for Age Observation Profile

element.name: identifier
element.definition: A unique identifier assigned to this observation.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: A plan, proposal or order that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this event. For example, a MedicationRequest may require a patient to have laboratory test performed before it is dispensed.

element.name: partOf
element.definition: A larger event of which this particular Observation is a component or step. For example, an observation as part of a procedure.
element.comment: To link an Observation to an Encounter use `encounter`. See the [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/observation.html#obsgrouping) below for guidance on referencing another Observation.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of the result value.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

element.name: category
element.definition: A code that classifies the general type of observation being made.
element.comment: In addition to the required category valueset, this element allows various categorization schemes based on the owner’s definition of the category and effectively multiple categories can be used at once. The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.

binding.name: ObservationCategory
binding.description: Codes for high level observation categories.

element.name: VSCat
element.definition: A code that classifies the general type of observation being made.
element.comment: In addition to the required category valueset, this element allows various categorization schemes based on the owner’s definition of the category and effectively multiple categories can be used at once. The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.

binding.name: ObservationCategory
binding.description: Codes for high level observation categories.

element.name: code
element.description: BMI percentile per age and sex for youth 2-20
element.definition: Coded Responses from C-CDA Vital Sign Results.
element.comment: additional codes that translate or map to this code are allowed. For example a more granular LOINC code or code that is used locally in a system.

binding.name: VitalSigns
binding.description: This identifies the vital sign result type.

element.name: subject
element.description: Who and/or what the observation is about
element.definition: The patient, or group of patients, location, or device this observation is about and into whose record the observation is placed. If the actual focus of the observation is different from the subject (or a sample of, part, or region of the subject), the `focus` element or the `code` itself specifies the actual focus of the observation.
element.comment: One would expect this element to be a cardinality of 1..1. The only circumstance in which the subject can be missing is when the observation is made by a device that does not know the patient. In this case, the observation SHALL be matched to a patient through some context/channel matching technique, and at this point, the observation should be updated.

element.name: focus
element.description: What the observation is about, when it is not about the subject of record
element.definition: The actual focus of an observation when it is not the patient of record representing something or someone associated with the patient such as a spouse, parent, fetus, or donor. For example, fetus observations in a mother's record. The focus of an observation could also be an existing condition, an intervention, the subject's diet, another observation of the subject, or a body structure such as tumor or implanted device. An example use case would be using the Observation resource to capture whether the mother is trained to change her child's tracheostomy tube. In this example, the child is the patient of record and the mother is the focus.
element.comment: Typically, an observation is made about the subject - a patient, or group of patients, location, or device - and the distinction between the subject and what is directly measured for an observation is specified in the observation code itself ( e.g., "Blood Glucose") and does not need to be represented separately using this element. Use `specimen` if a reference to a specimen is required. If a code is required instead of a resource use either `bodysite` for bodysites or the standard extension [focusCode](http://hl7.org/fhir/extension-observation-focuscode.html).

element.name: encounter
element.description: Healthcare event during which this observation is made
element.definition: The healthcare event (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this observation is made.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some events may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter (e.g. pre-admission laboratory tests).

element.name: effective
element.description: Often just a dateTime for Vital Signs
element.definition: Often just a dateTime for Vital Signs.
element.comment: At least a date should be present unless this observation is a historical report. For recording imprecise or "fuzzy" times (For example, a blood glucose measurement taken "after breakfast") use the [Timing](http://hl7.org/fhir/datatypes.html#timing) datatype which allow the measurement to be tied to regular life events.

constraint.name: vs-1
constraint.message: if Observation.effective[x] is dateTime and has a value then that value shall be precise to the day

element.name: issued
element.description: Date/Time this version was made available
element.definition: The date and time this version of the observation was made available to providers, typically after the results have been reviewed and verified.
element.comment: For Observations that don’t require review and verification, it may be the same as the [`lastUpdated` ](http://hl7.org/fhir/resource-definitions.html#Meta.lastUpdated) time of the resource itself. For Observations that do require review and verification for certain updates, it might not be the same as the `lastUpdated` time of the resource itself due to a non-clinically significant update that doesn’t require the new version to be reviewed and verified again.

element.name: performer
element.description: Who is responsible for the observation
element.definition: Who was responsible for asserting the observed value as "true".

element.name: value
element.description: Vital Signs value are recorded using the Quantity data type. For supporting observations such as Cuff size could use other datatypes such as CodeableConcept.
element.definition: Vital Signs value are recorded using the Quantity data type. For supporting observations such as Cuff size could use other datatypes such as CodeableConcept.
element.comment: An observation may have; 1) a single value here, 2) both a value and a set of related or component values, or 3) only a set of related or component values. If a value is present, the datatype for this element should be determined by Observation.code. A CodeableConcept with just a text would be used instead of a string if the field was usually coded, or if the type associated with the Observation.code defines a coded value. For additional guidance, see the [Notes section](http://hl7.org/fhir/observation.html#notes) below.

element.name: dataAbsentReason
element.definition: Provides a reason why the expected value in the element Observation.value[x] is missing.
element.comment:
Null or exceptional values can be represented two ways in FHIR Observations. One way is to simply include them in the value set and represent the exceptions in the value. For example, measurement values for a serology test could be "detected", "not detected", "inconclusive", or "specimen unsatisfactory".
The alternate way is to use the value element for actual observations and use the explicit dataAbsentReason element to record exceptional values. For example, the dataAbsentReason code "error" could be used when the measurement was not completed. Note that an observation may only be reported if there are values to report. For example differential cell counts values may be reported only when > 0. Because of these options, use-case agreements are required to interpret general observations for null or exceptional values.

binding.name: ObservationValueAbsentReason
binding.description: Codes specifying why the result (`Observation.value[x]`) is missing.

element.name: interpretation
element.definition: A categorical assessment of an observation value. For example, high, low, normal.
element.comment: Historically used for laboratory results (known as 'abnormal flag' ), its use extends to other use cases where coded interpretations are relevant. Often reported as one or more simple compact codes this element is often placed adjacent to the result value in reports and flow sheets to signal the meaning/normalcy status of the result.

binding.name: ObservationInterpretation
binding.description: Codes identifying interpretations of observations.

element.name: note
element.definition: Comments about the observation or the results.
element.comment: May include general statements about the observation, or statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable results values, or information about its source when relevant to its interpretation.

element.name: bodySite
element.definition: Indicates the site on the subject's body where the observation was made (i.e. the target site).
element.comment:
Only used if not implicit in code found in Observation.code. In many systems, this may be represented as a related observation instead of an inline component.
If the use case requires BodySite to be handled as a separate resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension[ bodySite](http://hl7.org/fhir/extension-bodysite.html).

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.name: method
element.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to perform the observation.
element.comment: Only used if not implicit in code for Observation.code.

binding.name: ObservationMethod
binding.description: Methods for simple observations.

Also note that observation resources may be used in contexts that track the specimen explicitly (e.g. Diagnostic Report).

Systems MAY choose to restrict to only supplying the relevant reference range based on knowledge about the patient (e.g., specific to the patient's age, gender, weight and other factors), but this might not be possible or appropriate. Whenever more than one reference range is supplied, the differences between them SHOULD be provided in the reference range and/or age properties.

constraint.name: obs-3
constraint.message: Must have at least a low or a high or text

element.description: Used when reporting vital signs panel components
element.definition: Used when reporting vital signs panel components.
element.comment: When using this element, an observation will typically have either a value or a set of related resources, although both may be present in some cases. element.description: Used when reporting systolic and diastolic blood pressure.

element.comment: For a discussion on the ways Observations can be assembled in groups together see [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/observation.html#notes) below.

element.definition: Oxygen Saturation.

binding.name: VitalSigns
binding.description: This identifies the vital sign result type.

element.name: OxygenSatCode
element.description: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information. Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labeled as UserSelected = true.
